description: In this course, users will learn foundations for capturing video and how to edit in Premiere Pro, the leading video editing software from the Adobe Creative Cloud suite. Topics include importing media, using the timeline, adding transitions and effects, mixing audio, color correction, and exporting options.
descriptionMD: In this course, users will learn foundations for capturing video and how to edit in Premiere Pro, the leading video editing software from the Adobe Creative Cloud suite. Topics include importing media, using the timeline, adding transitions and effects, mixing audio, color correction, and exporting options.
name: Premiere Pro CC 2017
subtitle: Video Editing Application

episodes.description: James and Vonne introduce commonly used terminology for working in video editing and Premiere Pro.
episodes.title: Read Me
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:05.466
[SOUND]

2
00:00:05.466 --> 00:00:11.517
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.517 --> 00:00:14.153
Hello everyone and
welcome to Creative Pro TV.

4
00:00:14.153 --> 00:00:17.095
I'm your host, Vonne Smith, and

5
00:00:17.095 --> 00:00:22.984
we are starting a brand new series
in Adobe Premiere Pro CC 2017.

6
00:00:22.984 --> 00:00:27.880
And we're really excited to have the one
and only, the expert, Mr. James Biddle.

7
00:00:27.880 --> 00:00:30.763
[LAUGH]
>> Great, thanks for making it easy on me.

8
00:00:30.763 --> 00:00:33.423
>> I know, I love when Daniel does that.

9
00:00:33.423 --> 00:00:38.420
The total expert on this, like well-
>> No pressure, no pressure, no pressure.

10
00:00:38.420 --> 00:00:39.360
>> I know, right?

11
00:00:39.360 --> 00:00:40.498
[LAUGH]
>> Goodness.

12
00:00:40.498 --> 00:00:41.951
Well Vonne, it's great to be here.

13
00:00:41.951 --> 00:00:44.065
>> I know, well I'm really excited for
this series-

14
00:00:44.065 --> 00:00:45.085
>> Me too.

15
00:00:45.085 --> 00:00:47.160
>> To learn all about our Premiere and
some video editing.

16
00:00:47.160 --> 00:00:49.154
And we're starting from
the very beginning.

17
00:00:49.154 --> 00:00:50.280
>> Yep.
>> We're gonna take it from

18
00:00:50.280 --> 00:00:53.725
a base level and move up, because we
talked about it, and this is our overview.

19
00:00:53.725 --> 00:00:54.660
>> Yeah.

20
00:00:54.660 --> 00:00:56.363
>> We're actually filming this last, and

21
00:00:56.363 --> 00:00:59.381
we've actually gone through all
the episodes and I've learned a lot.

22
00:00:59.381 --> 00:01:01.944
>> Good.
>> But I wanted to kind of go ahead and

23
00:01:01.944 --> 00:01:06.213
just get a quick frame of reference for
just some terminology.

24
00:01:06.213 --> 00:01:08.383
And I love how we-
>> Sure.

25
00:01:08.383 --> 00:01:10.066
>> Read me cuz-
>> Yeah, the read me file,

26
00:01:10.066 --> 00:01:11.369
no one ever reads the read me file.

27
00:01:11.369 --> 00:01:13.507
>> Right [LAUGH]
>> Read the read me file.

28
00:01:13.507 --> 00:01:15.307
>> Yes, read the instructions.

29
00:01:15.307 --> 00:01:16.155
>> Please read the instructions.

30
00:01:16.155 --> 00:01:20.972
>> And so one thing that I do
when I'm learning a product is

31
00:01:20.972 --> 00:01:24.233
I wanna know the right terminology.

32
00:01:24.233 --> 00:01:29.270
>> Yeah.
>> So that way I can use it wrongly.

33
00:01:29.270 --> 00:01:34.263
>> Exactly, we do have some standardized
language within editing and within Adobe,

34
00:01:34.263 --> 00:01:37.772
but you're always going to
say something that's close.

35
00:01:37.772 --> 00:01:42.496
For example, the timeline is a tool and
sequences go in it, but

36
00:01:42.496 --> 00:01:47.773
everybody just says show me the sequence,
show me the sequence tool.

37
00:01:47.773 --> 00:01:48.286
>> Yeah.

38
00:01:48.286 --> 00:01:50.355
>> I mean it just happens that way.

39
00:01:50.355 --> 00:01:54.381
>> Yeah,and I think it's from just being
in the industry and you just start using

40
00:01:54.381 --> 00:01:58.529
this terminology and you just use it like
it's regular language for you, but for

41
00:01:58.529 --> 00:02:02.572
me like an outsider coming in, it's like
wait, was that a sequence or a clip?

42
00:02:02.572 --> 00:02:05.590
Wait, is it a clip and
a media the same thing?

43
00:02:05.590 --> 00:02:07.870
>> It's a media and file and
then everything's going crazy so, yeah.

44
00:02:07.870 --> 00:02:09.828
There are some things you
wanna embed in there.

45
00:02:09.828 --> 00:02:11.414
Don't get it wrong but

46
00:02:11.414 --> 00:02:15.920
in other cases you can fudge out
a couple of times, it's okay.

47
00:02:15.920 --> 00:02:19.870
>> Yeah, cuz I know when we go
through all these episodes you

48
00:02:19.870 --> 00:02:22.420
really explain all of this and
I'm, I get it.

49
00:02:22.420 --> 00:02:25.987
But it took me a couple episodes to
kinda clear it in my mind of exactly

50
00:02:25.987 --> 00:02:27.689
the sequence and the segments.

51
00:02:27.689 --> 00:02:29.282
>> Sure.
>> So I've actually made a few notes.

52
00:02:29.282 --> 00:02:30.245
>> Okay.
>> If you don't mind,

53
00:02:30.245 --> 00:02:32.501
I'm just gonna go ahead and
ask you a few things and

54
00:02:32.501 --> 00:02:34.614
do a quick overview of
explaining something.

55
00:02:34.614 --> 00:02:37.907
>> Hit me with the notes, just don't
hit me like you hit me after the show.

56
00:02:37.907 --> 00:02:38.407
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay.

57
00:02:38.407 --> 00:02:39.440
>> [LAUGH] All right, I'll-

58
00:02:39.440 --> 00:02:40.039
>> Help me.

59
00:02:40.039 --> 00:02:41.367
>> I'll be gentle. [LAUGH] >> All right.

60
00:02:41.367 --> 00:02:42.178
Good.

61
00:02:42.178 --> 00:02:43.940
>> So we have media versus clip,

62
00:02:43.940 --> 00:02:47.650
is it the same thing?
>> Right, okay, no.

63
00:02:47.650 --> 00:02:49.887
So media is essence, it's what you shot on

64
00:02:49.887 --> 00:02:54.174
your camera or it's the actual file that
you've, you can see it as a quick timer,

65
00:02:54.174 --> 00:02:58.589
a JPEG, or something like that.
Once it is brought into Premiere,

66
00:02:58.589 --> 00:03:02.171
it becomes what we call a clip or
a masterclip.

67
00:03:02.171 --> 00:03:04.138
That is metadata that

68
00:03:04.138 --> 00:03:08.100
represents the media.
And that's why clips, you can change.

69
00:03:08.100 --> 00:03:09.780
You can make them longer or shorter.

70
00:03:09.780 --> 00:03:10.501
You can rename them.

71
00:03:10.501 --> 00:03:12.452
You can add effects to them and

72
00:03:12.452 --> 00:03:16.232
it doesn't affect the actual media.
It stays the same.

73
00:03:16.232 --> 00:03:17.840
>> It's kinda like a nickname,

74
00:03:17.840 --> 00:03:21.389
like we're nicknaming this
particular thing that's [CROSSTALK]

75
00:03:21.389 --> 00:03:23.223
>> Nicknaming or I often say,

76
00:03:23.223 --> 00:03:26.985
the media is the parts and
the clip is the instructions.

77
00:03:26.985 --> 00:03:28.029
And I can change it,

78
00:03:28.029 --> 00:03:32.148
I could rewrite the instructions, put it
in a nice glossy binder, do all that,

79
00:03:32.148 --> 00:03:34.251
doesn't change the parts.
>> Okay.

80
00:03:34.251 --> 00:03:34.763
>> Yeah.

81
00:03:34.763 --> 00:03:36.087
>> Great, all right, wonderful.

82
00:03:36.087 --> 00:03:38.823
Now when we talk about audio, I feel it's

83
00:03:38.823 --> 00:03:43.904
the whole of how we capture it and then
there's an audio clip cuz we understand

84
00:03:43.904 --> 00:03:47.170
that clips when it's coming to Premiere.
>> Right.

85
00:03:47.170 --> 00:03:48.775
>> But then when it goes somewhere

86
00:03:48.775 --> 00:03:50.975
else it becomes a track?
>> Right,

87
00:03:50.975 --> 00:03:52.760
so-
>> Or am I jumping the gun a little?

88
00:03:52.760 --> 00:03:54.290
>> No, no, no, you're fine, you're fine.

89
00:03:54.290 --> 00:03:56.560
The thing is when you get into audio,

90
00:03:56.560 --> 00:03:59.910
people who do an audio has a very,
very specialized language,

91
00:03:59.910 --> 00:04:02.260
mostly because they don't
want to talk to anybody else.

92
00:04:02.260 --> 00:04:05.030
And if you don't speak their language
they'll just go, [SOUND] and walk away.

93
00:04:05.030 --> 00:04:09.200
When we bring in media, okay?

94
00:04:09.200 --> 00:04:15.100
We think of that as input and
we say that something has channels.

95
00:04:15.100 --> 00:04:18.470
So if you record on a camera,
you have two channels maybe, or

96
00:04:18.470 --> 00:04:20.550
some cameras record like eight channels.

97
00:04:20.550 --> 00:04:23.260
Or maybe you recorded on a device
that gave you four channels.

98
00:04:23.260 --> 00:04:25.362
That's considered an input.

99
00:04:25.362 --> 00:04:30.285
So when you put it into a sequence,
that's when you see

100
00:04:30.285 --> 00:04:35.325
movies where guys do a mixer and
doing stuff like [SOUND].

101
00:04:35.325 --> 00:04:35.871
>> Mm-hm.

102
00:04:35.871 --> 00:04:38.590
>> And they say we need more tracks, man.

103
00:04:38.590 --> 00:04:41.934
That's the thing is that
on the output side,

104
00:04:41.934 --> 00:04:45.430
which is the sequence side,
you have tracks.

105
00:04:45.430 --> 00:04:49.686
And that's why something with
two channels, or eight channels,

106
00:04:49.686 --> 00:04:51.137
can go in to one track.

107
00:04:51.137 --> 00:04:52.670
>> And that's where I use the wrong C.

108
00:04:53.690 --> 00:04:56.237
I said clips but when you said channels,
I was yes, that's right.

109
00:04:56.237 --> 00:04:56.840
>> Channels.

110
00:04:56.840 --> 00:04:58.090
>> Cuz you were saying channels.

111
00:04:58.090 --> 00:05:01.700
And I think that's another one where
there's the input and the output are like,

112
00:05:01.700 --> 00:05:04.930
how you captured it with your device-
>> Right.

113
00:05:04.930 --> 00:05:09.410
>> When it comes into Premiere and
then how it goes out of Premiere and

114
00:05:09.410 --> 00:05:10.800
all that kind of stuff-
>> Exactly.

115
00:05:10.800 --> 00:05:13.700
I think we talked a couple of times,
I like to think

116
00:05:13.700 --> 00:05:18.020
of the left side as the input side and
the right side is the output side.

117
00:05:18.020 --> 00:05:21.895
That's why you have different language,
like we have clips and channels and

118
00:05:21.895 --> 00:05:26.261
gain for audio, when we're adjusting how
loud or soft it is, we're adjusting gain.

119
00:05:26.261 --> 00:05:28.932
Cuz we always said on audio input,
you have gain.

120
00:05:28.932 --> 00:05:31.907
On output, you have volume.

121
00:05:31.907 --> 00:05:33.450
>> Yes.

122
00:05:33.450 --> 00:05:37.062
>> So left side, we have clips,
we have channels, we have gain.

123
00:05:37.062 --> 00:05:41.090
On the right side,
which is the output side,

124
00:05:41.090 --> 00:05:45.980
we have segments, we have volume,
and we have tracks.

125
00:05:45.980 --> 00:05:47.180
>> Yeah, and we explain all of this.

126
00:05:47.180 --> 00:05:50.040
You explain it very well
in all these episodes.

127
00:05:50.040 --> 00:05:54.340
So again, we're just doing
listen to the terminology.

128
00:05:54.340 --> 00:05:55.530
When we're saying left and right,

129
00:05:55.530 --> 00:06:00.310
we're talking about the physical
sides of the program.

130
00:06:00.310 --> 00:06:04.386
>> We can take a quick look right
now at the interface, okay?

131
00:06:04.386 --> 00:06:07.190
Because what we do is we have panels.

132
00:06:07.190 --> 00:06:09.530
So we have panels, we have panel groups.

133
00:06:09.530 --> 00:06:12.795
And then everything that's
sort of on the left side.

134
00:06:12.795 --> 00:06:16.325
Okay, everything that's on
this left side right here.

135
00:06:16.325 --> 00:06:19.953
The source and the project,
that's what I'm considering the left side,

136
00:06:19.953 --> 00:06:22.442
the input side because this
where we get our clips.

137
00:06:22.442 --> 00:06:27.891
The source area is where we take
a clip and we modify it, okay?

138
00:06:27.891 --> 00:06:34.960
I'm only gonna take this much right here,
and you'll learn this as I'm doing it.

139
00:06:34.960 --> 00:06:39.332
I have marked a segment of
this that I'm going to use,

140
00:06:39.332 --> 00:06:43.033
and then I bring it down
here to the sequence.

141
00:06:43.033 --> 00:06:49.081
And now I've used a segment of this clip
which now I can adjust it to volume or

142
00:06:49.081 --> 00:06:52.640
on this side I could've adjusted its gain.

143
00:06:52.640 --> 00:06:55.880
>> Yeah and see right there, the whole,
okay here is the clip we went in and

144
00:06:55.880 --> 00:06:56.477
the source.

145
00:06:56.477 --> 00:07:00.704
That's not a part of just understanding
the names of the windows or

146
00:07:00.704 --> 00:07:03.798
panels, cuz we use those
words interchangeably

147
00:07:03.798 --> 00:07:07.362
within what we call the workspace
of any Adobe product.

148
00:07:07.362 --> 00:07:08.894
>> Yeah.

149
00:07:08.894 --> 00:07:11.054
Cuz all of these window panel
thingies that we go in.

150
00:07:11.054 --> 00:07:12.858
>> Right.
>> So it's like project,

151
00:07:12.858 --> 00:07:16.205
okay that's that name, source,
and then it comes down.

152
00:07:16.205 --> 00:07:19.030
Again that terminology of go up, go up,

153
00:07:19.030 --> 00:07:19.620
go up and-
>> Right.

154
00:07:19.620 --> 00:07:20.540
>> Yes, that's right.

155
00:07:20.540 --> 00:07:22.055
>> And that's the thing I couldn't say.

156
00:07:22.055 --> 00:07:25.320
Cuz technically this is
the project panel group.

157
00:07:25.320 --> 00:07:26.750
And there are things within it.

158
00:07:26.750 --> 00:07:27.712
This is the source panel group.

159
00:07:27.712 --> 00:07:30.810
The source panel which has a panel group.

160
00:07:30.810 --> 00:07:34.130
And I could make that very clear
the entire time, but then I would go very,

161
00:07:34.130 --> 00:07:37.940
very slow and be worried more about
saying it correctly than having fun and

162
00:07:37.940 --> 00:07:38.630
showing you what to do.

163
00:07:38.630 --> 00:07:40.690
>> Yeah.
>> One last thing I want to show about

164
00:07:40.690 --> 00:07:43.260
the left-right, and
to explain channel tracks.

165
00:07:44.600 --> 00:07:46.190
This left side in the sequence,

166
00:07:46.190 --> 00:07:50.640
and we're gonna talk about this
several times, represents the source.

167
00:07:50.640 --> 00:07:55.080
And it has a video channel and
an audio channel.

168
00:07:55.080 --> 00:08:02.808
This represents the sequence which has
three video tracks and four audio tracks.

169
00:08:02.808 --> 00:08:09.380
>> That's where you're actually
doing all of the editing.

170
00:08:09.380 --> 00:08:10.408
>> Right, that's where we actually.

171
00:08:10.408 --> 00:08:14.418
>> Even within Premiere, we can do all
these, I keep calling them layers, and

172
00:08:14.418 --> 00:08:18.490
I keep referring to it throughout the
series, because I see it as layers, but

173
00:08:18.490 --> 00:08:20.079
these are tracks [CROSSTALK].

174
00:08:20.079 --> 00:08:24.142
>> If you're a Photoshop user or even
sometimes an After Effects user coming

175
00:08:24.142 --> 00:08:28.418
into Premiere, you're gonna use
the language that you're used to, okay?

176
00:08:28.418 --> 00:08:30.973
And eventually you'll realize
when you bounce back and

177
00:08:30.973 --> 00:08:34.890
forth between applications there's new
terms of different terms because different

178
00:08:34.890 --> 00:08:37.515
types of professionals use
different apps all the time.

179
00:08:37.515 --> 00:08:40.441
It happens, don't feel bad, yeah.

180
00:08:40.441 --> 00:08:42.456
Some people are just gonna tell you, well,

181
00:08:42.456 --> 00:08:44.530
they actually really
should be same tracks.

182
00:08:44.530 --> 00:08:46.070
I mean, it's fine.

183
00:08:46.070 --> 00:08:46.660
>> Yeah.

184
00:08:46.660 --> 00:08:48.570
>> Just take the ribbing and move on.

185
00:08:48.570 --> 00:08:49.223
>> Yeah, exactly.
And

186
00:08:49.223 --> 00:08:53.029
it's because I've been with you this
whole week and you're going through this.

187
00:08:53.029 --> 00:08:53.588
>> Right.

188
00:08:53.588 --> 00:08:55.217
Yep, there's that terminology.

189
00:08:55.217 --> 00:08:58.485
It's already clicking,
the more you hear it and

190
00:08:58.485 --> 00:09:03.583
the more you see it in action as we go
through everything, it will get it, but

191
00:09:03.583 --> 00:09:09.028
I just wanted to kinda go through some of
those super basics of what is a sequence-

192
00:09:09.028 --> 00:09:09.842
>> Right.

193
00:09:09.842 --> 00:09:12.270
>> Because the sequence is over on
the timeline, and that's where-

194
00:09:12.270 --> 00:09:13.185
>> Yep.

195
00:09:13.185 --> 00:09:15.311
>> We'll be doing the editing,

196
00:09:15.311 --> 00:09:19.085
but the segments are what
you want out of your clips.

197
00:09:19.085 --> 00:09:20.611
[CROSSTALK] that was your media.

198
00:09:20.611 --> 00:09:22.668
>> And then it becomes a game.

199
00:09:22.668 --> 00:09:23.725
>> Yeah.

200
00:09:23.725 --> 00:09:24.352
>> [LAUGH] Right.
>> Yeah.

201
00:09:24.352 --> 00:09:28.762
And so we'll use different words-
>> Yeah.

202
00:09:28.762 --> 00:09:32.300
>> Throughout here, but we're just kinda-
>> And you'll catch us doing that and

203
00:09:32.300 --> 00:09:32.854
fun with it.

204
00:09:32.854 --> 00:09:37.201
Have fun with the fact that you caught
us saying maybe something slightly,

205
00:09:37.201 --> 00:09:38.850
have fun with it please.

206
00:09:38.850 --> 00:09:43.350
>> Yeah, because I do the same
thing that the That's not right.

207
00:09:43.350 --> 00:09:44.175
>> No, no, no.

208
00:09:44.175 --> 00:09:45.977
>> No, bad kitty.
>> Bad kitty.

209
00:09:45.977 --> 00:09:46.564
>> [LAUGH] Exactly.
So

210
00:09:46.564 --> 00:09:48.599
I just want to kind of get a frame-up and

211
00:09:48.599 --> 00:09:51.018
we do mention a lot about
hot keys in this show.

212
00:09:51.018 --> 00:09:53.030
>> Yep, we talk a lot about hot keys.

213
00:09:53.030 --> 00:09:54.570
There are some very simple ones.

214
00:09:54.570 --> 00:09:59.010
The ones that I mention are the ones you
probably gonna want to commit to memory or

215
00:09:59.010 --> 00:09:59.920
write down.

216
00:09:59.920 --> 00:10:02.870
And then again,
I will show this several times,

217
00:10:02.870 --> 00:10:04.380
I'm just gonna go back
to Premiere Pro here.

218
00:10:04.380 --> 00:10:08.845
There is a keyboard shortcuts area
that you can fire up and look through.

219
00:10:08.845 --> 00:10:14.363
The other thing is too, I didn't really
mention this in lessons, but one

220
00:10:14.363 --> 00:10:20.160
thing that a lot of people do is instead
of adding or modifying, they remove.

221
00:10:21.210 --> 00:10:25.220
Because they don't use a lot, and they
will basically clear the keyboard out as

222
00:10:25.220 --> 00:10:27.960
much as they can and
then only add in what they need.

223
00:10:29.040 --> 00:10:31.706
>> Yeah, so I think it's just
how you wanna approach it but

224
00:10:31.706 --> 00:10:33.255
put in those hot keys to memory.

225
00:10:33.255 --> 00:10:37.952
And in the show notes, we do have a link
to the Adobe website that has shortcuts

226
00:10:37.952 --> 00:10:39.554
for both Windows and Mac.

227
00:10:39.554 --> 00:10:42.687
And here is another side note,
we are using a Mac here-

228
00:10:42.687 --> 00:10:43.780
>> Yep, we're just using a Mac.

229
00:10:43.780 --> 00:10:47.112

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne discuss the basics for getting started in Premiere Pro by exploring the different settings when you first launch the program and create a new file. They also determine why it is best to use the media browser in Premiere Pro rather than the Finder and explain the concepts of scratch disks and ingest media.
episodes.title: Getting Started in Premiere Pro

00:20:54.760 --> 00:20:55.787

episodes.description: Organizing media for your Premiere Pro project is an important first step to making a great video. This episode explores the project panel, the source monitor panel, and the program monitor in the Premiere Pro interface. We also determine why blue is so important to notice in working within the panels.
episodes.title: Project Organization

Since I already have it on the hard drive,

In this case I'm gonna create some

Cuz a lot of people buy big cameras,

00:09:50.047 --> 00:09:51.423

00:09:53.326 --> 00:09:54.644

I'll do the Cmd+A, Ctrl+click, and Import.

And these are just gonna just

206

these are much smaller files,

00:10:47.790 --> 00:10:50.860

So you can go through this very quickly.

00:23:31.940 --> 00:23:33.783

core Hundreds of pieces of footage and

That kind of metadata for

you to organize yourself

00:24:54.130 --> 00:24:59.880

The reason why it gives you a name is

But coming back in the next

we'll have some fun

499
00:25:38.700 --> 00:25:39.630
>> All right, great and

again this is like basic
>> Information that they,

some people kind of scrub over,
>> Scrub over it's like get in no, no,no,

you don't have to go clicking around.

00:25:49.585 --> 00:25:52.735
You can create these things that will help

If you're spending all your

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne take a deeper dive into organizing projects, introduce the left side vs the right side, and add custom meta data columns to items in the project panel.
episodes.title: Even More Project Organization

Maybe ten times in a session and
you're doing it with a mouse.

374
00:18:55.280 --> 00:18:57.350
Please, just make a button.

375
00:18:57.350 --> 00:19:00.610
Cuz you're doing it so much that, yeah.

376
00:19:00.610 --> 00:19:02.280
>> And that does come with experience.

377
00:19:02.280 --> 00:19:03.270
>> It does, yeah.

378
00:19:03.270 --> 00:19:06.660
>> And this is good experience for
us, to make sure that we know how to

379
00:19:06.660 --> 00:19:09.630
organize ourselves,
be able to get around really fast.

380
00:19:09.630 --> 00:19:11.020
And like you said,
we're gonna go ahead and

381
00:19:11.020 --> 00:19:13.890
now put all that stuff into our timeline,
and then make a little clip.

382
00:19:13.890 --> 00:19:17.540
Well, we're gonna make
a project with our clips.

383
00:19:17.540 --> 00:19:19.350
>> We're gonna make
a project with your clips,

384
00:19:19.350 --> 00:19:20.930
we're gonna make
a timeline in the project.

385
00:19:20.930 --> 00:19:22.571
>> Yeah, gotta use that terminology!

386
00:19:22.571 --> 00:19:23.461
[CROSSTALK] Yeah.

387
00:19:23.461 --> 00:19:24.790
Well, thank you so much for that-
>> Thank you.

388
00:19:24.790 --> 00:19:25.380
>> Information.

389
00:19:25.380 --> 00:19:27.890
But we are going to go ahead and
close this episode.

390
00:19:27.890 --> 00:19:31.560
So signing off for creative ProTV,
I'm your host Vonne Smith.

391
00:19:31.560 --> 00:19:32.300
>> I'm Jim Biddle.

392
00:19:32.300 --> 00:19:33.971
>> And we'll see you soon.

393
00:19:33.971 --> 00:19:43.129
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, we examine the source monitor panel buttons, options, shortcuts for previewing clips, adding in and out points, and creating segments to add to the project panel. James also demonstrates how to create custom keyboard shortcuts in Premiere Pro.
episodes.title: The Source Monitor
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.460
[SOUND]

2
00:00:05.460 --> 00:00:11.185
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.185 --> 00:00:15.009
Hello, and welcome to another
edition of CreativeProTV.

4
00:00:15.009 --> 00:00:16.850
My name is Vonne Smith and

5
00:00:16.850 --> 00:00:21.691
we are continuing on with our
Adobe Premiere CC 2017 series.

6
00:00:21.691 --> 00:00:25.961
And we have in the studios yet
again, our Mr. James Biddle.

7
00:00:25.961 --> 00:00:26.546
How are you doing?

8
00:00:26.546 --> 00:00:28.358
>> Hi, I'm back, I'm here, it's great.

9
00:00:28.358 --> 00:00:29.976
>> I just said James, and
I've been saying Jim.

10
00:00:29.976 --> 00:00:31.345
>> Well, you can say whatever you want.

11
00:00:31.345 --> 00:00:33.012
>> I mean, I guess you are James.

12
00:00:33.012 --> 00:00:34.503
>> Well, I am so many things.

13
00:00:34.503 --> 00:00:37.382
>> [LAUGH] You are, well,
I'm glad that you're with us again.

14
00:00:37.382 --> 00:00:39.285
>> I'm hoping people out
in the audience are going,

15
00:00:39.285 --> 00:00:40.929
can they edit that out
in Adobe real quick?

16
00:00:40.929 --> 00:00:43.636
>> [LAUGH] Right,
I think we can do that on the timeline.

17
00:00:43.636 --> 00:00:46.123
>> Sound is the worst part so, okay.

18
00:00:46.123 --> 00:00:48.501
>> [LAUGH] We know all about that here.

19
00:00:48.501 --> 00:00:50.442
>> We know all about that, okay.

20
00:00:50.442 --> 00:00:52.268
>> Let's just not hope it,
we don't want it to rain.

21
00:00:52.268 --> 00:00:53.536
>> Nope we don't want it to do that.

22
00:00:53.536 --> 00:00:54.516
Let's not do that.

23
00:00:54.516 --> 00:00:55.251
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

24
00:00:55.251 --> 00:00:55.751
>> Cool.

25
00:00:55.751 --> 00:00:56.545
>> So we've been

26
00:00:56.545 --> 00:00:59.096
talking about the source monitor.
>> That's right.

27
00:00:59.096 --> 00:01:00.299
We're going a little bit

28
00:01:00.299 --> 00:01:04.001
away from organization now.
Because remember, the project panel,

29
00:01:04.001 --> 00:01:08.464
sometimes called the project window,
is where we organize all of our sources,

30
00:01:08.464 --> 00:01:12.361
most likely called master clips.
Eventually we're gonna get into having

31
00:01:12.361 --> 00:01:16.268
titles in there, even some effects and
some sequences and some other things that

32
00:01:16.268 --> 00:01:18.901
are kind of a little mind blowing.
But like I said,

33
00:01:18.901 --> 00:01:21.066
this is just to keep it simple.
It's like you

34
00:01:21.066 --> 00:01:25.400
wanna get something in there, you wanna
make it, export it, and you're done.

35
00:01:25.400 --> 00:01:27.380
And then maybe you'll do it again,
who knows?

36
00:01:27.380 --> 00:01:30.020
So now we're going to
the source monitor and

37
00:01:30.020 --> 00:01:34.770
we've been talking about the idea that
there's this right side and the left side.

38
00:01:34.770 --> 00:01:36.870
We're still on the left side.

39
00:01:36.870 --> 00:01:38.130
It's kinda like when we read.

40
00:01:38.130 --> 00:01:40.320
We go from left to right, okay?

41
00:01:40.320 --> 00:01:43.350
So right now, we're still working on
the left and we have a certain language.

42
00:01:43.350 --> 00:01:46.614
We have a source monitor over there,

43
00:01:46.614 --> 00:01:51.152
we have a project panel,
and we have clips, okay?

44
00:01:51.152 --> 00:01:53.454
And we're gonna transfer
them into something else.

45
00:01:53.454 --> 00:01:56.958
So if we go back to the computer,
I've loaded some, all right?

46
00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:59.628
And let me zoom in real quick, okay?

47
00:01:59.628 --> 00:02:04.503
Up here and again what happens is
when people sort of start this,

48
00:02:04.503 --> 00:02:07.589
they find a little bit of this daunting.

49
00:02:07.589 --> 00:02:11.378
But using our left to right rule,
just follow things left to right, and

50
00:02:11.378 --> 00:02:12.660
it'll be fine.

51
00:02:12.660 --> 00:02:15.390
It's telling us it's the source panel.

52
00:02:15.390 --> 00:02:22.685
And we're looking at this particular clip,
MVI_0078 and it's an MPEG-4, okay.

53
00:02:22.685 --> 00:02:25.409
That's the one we are looking at,
that's the one that's currently loaded.

54
00:02:25.409 --> 00:02:28.937
If I come over to this control menu,
I can load other ones or

55
00:02:28.937 --> 00:02:32.983
I can do that fancy trick which I'm
gonna change up in a little bit.

56
00:02:32.983 --> 00:02:38.880
I also have another panel, affects
controls, an audio clip mixer, metadata.

57
00:02:38.880 --> 00:02:40.220
What's this thing?

58
00:02:40.220 --> 00:02:43.730
Well sometimes all the panels
don't fit into the main panel.

59
00:02:43.730 --> 00:02:47.430
So if I click this,
I can choose them from here.

60
00:02:47.430 --> 00:02:51.320
Or if I add more to this one,
it shows me what I'm not seeing.

61
00:02:51.320 --> 00:02:53.934
It was the same, it's in all the panels.

62
00:02:53.934 --> 00:02:57.370
Okay, so now what do I do to
sort of navigate through this?

63
00:02:57.370 --> 00:03:00.290
That hover scrub thing
doesn't work anymore, boo.

64
00:03:00.290 --> 00:03:02.540
Well, it's a little bit different.

65
00:03:04.110 --> 00:03:05.510
Here we have many things.

66
00:03:05.510 --> 00:03:08.990
I'm gonna start.
This was where is the playhead position?

67
00:03:08.990 --> 00:03:11.630
If I click this and move it back and
forth, it moves the.

68
00:03:11.630 --> 00:03:13.383
There it is, hey Puppet Seymour.

69
00:03:13.383 --> 00:03:15.020
How's it going, buddy?

70
00:03:15.020 --> 00:03:16.880
He's funny,
he's going to eat those tomatoes.

71
00:03:16.880 --> 00:03:17.595
Yummy yum yum yum.

72
00:03:17.595 --> 00:03:19.300
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay, so I can do that.

73
00:03:19.300 --> 00:03:22.390
I can hold and grab this.

74
00:03:22.390 --> 00:03:28.350
Now I have a thing here called Fit,
also known as Select Zoom Level.

75
00:03:28.350 --> 00:03:35.018
What that means is if there's
something that I want to boom, 25%.

76
00:03:35.018 --> 00:03:42.304
Or something like 150% or
go all the way down to 10%.

77
00:03:42.304 --> 00:03:46.738
Occasionally there might be some things
that we do with Effects where we need to

78
00:03:46.738 --> 00:03:50.645
see slightly outside the picture
to manipulate things for Effects.

79
00:03:50.645 --> 00:03:52.331
Right now if I just do Fit,

80
00:03:52.331 --> 00:03:56.412
or what we often call fit the window,
it is now fit to the panel.

81
00:03:56.412 --> 00:03:59.600
This means drag video only,
which we'll get into in editing.

82
00:03:59.600 --> 00:04:02.415
This means drag audio only, however,

83
00:04:02.415 --> 00:04:06.179
if I just click them,
these are my audio wave forms.

84
00:04:06.179 --> 00:04:11.079
I don't have a lot of audio on here right
now, you can see a few bumps, okay,

85
00:04:11.079 --> 00:04:13.007
and I can go back to the video.

86
00:04:13.007 --> 00:04:17.667
Full, half, quarter, or eighth.

87
00:04:17.667 --> 00:04:23.683
Sometimes, when you got big media,
lots of color, lots of motion,

88
00:04:23.683 --> 00:04:30.354
when you play it back at full resolution,
it might tax your ram a little bit.

89
00:04:30.354 --> 00:04:32.449
All systems have this.

90
00:04:32.449 --> 00:04:34.029
This should be your bare minimum on RAM.

91
00:04:34.029 --> 00:04:36.879
Well, yours might be
below the bare minimum.

92
00:04:36.879 --> 00:04:41.338
So you can do is say actually play it back
at like a quarter of the resolution and

93
00:04:41.338 --> 00:04:44.440
it's gonna look fuzzy and
not so great once I play it.

94
00:04:45.790 --> 00:04:49.620
But when it stops,
it'll go back to full resolution.

95
00:04:49.620 --> 00:04:50.924
I can look at it the whole time.

96
00:04:50.924 --> 00:04:54.130
And if you export it,
it's gonna export at the full resolution.

97
00:04:54.130 --> 00:04:57.610
I'm paranoid, I'd change it back to full
resolution just because I'm paranoid.

98
00:04:57.610 --> 00:05:00.270
Once again, we have settings.

99
00:05:00.270 --> 00:05:05.840
Playback resolution, pause resolutions,
Loop, if you want things to loop or

100
00:05:05.840 --> 00:05:10.320
certain things to show or not show, okay?

101
00:05:10.320 --> 00:05:12.960
We're gonna get the audio timing and
it's in a minute that will be interesting.

102
00:05:15.400 --> 00:05:19.580
This is how long this clip actually is.

103
00:05:19.580 --> 00:05:23.150
It is 46 seconds and 26 frames.

104
00:05:23.150 --> 00:05:26.480
Okay, so it goes hours,
minutes, seconds, frames.

105
00:05:26.480 --> 00:05:29.200
It is technically called the in and
out duration and here's why.

106
00:05:30.280 --> 00:05:33.860
Yes, I can move this, okay?

107
00:05:33.860 --> 00:05:35.643
I can do it with the spacebar.

108
00:05:38.631 --> 00:05:40.912
Now, if you are occasionally like me,

109
00:05:40.912 --> 00:05:46.420
you wanna work with the keyboard, and the
mouse, at the same time, with both hands.

110
00:05:46.420 --> 00:05:51.910
Okay, so, if you're planning on it
right now, and you've got some media,

111
00:05:51.910 --> 00:05:57.500
I want you to put your left hand over J,
K and L because what I can do is this.

112
00:05:57.500 --> 00:05:59.920
I can hit L and it plays forward.

113
00:06:01.000 --> 00:06:04.830
Then I can pause it with K and
then play it backward with J.

114
00:06:06.010 --> 00:06:09.877
Now if I hold K, hold down on K and tap L,

115
00:06:09.877 --> 00:06:15.520
you'll notice the playheads
moving one frame at a time.

116
00:06:15.520 --> 00:06:18.619
Or in this case, because it was recorded
on a cell phone, it seems to jump.

117
00:06:18.619 --> 00:06:22.404
It'll jump a couple of frames because,
again, when you're working with phones,

118
00:06:22.404 --> 00:06:24.660
sometimes you'll get an odd
time code like that.

119
00:06:24.660 --> 00:06:27.890
I'll do the same thing with J,
where I can work back a frame at a time.

120
00:06:27.890 --> 00:06:30.390
>> But is that just with phone footage,
or is that-

121
00:06:30.390 --> 00:06:31.798
>> Yeah, usually with phone footage

122
00:06:31.798 --> 00:06:33.259
because of the way it handles
>> Okay.

123
00:06:33.259 --> 00:06:33.824
>> Time code.

124
00:06:33.824 --> 00:06:38.920
If I keep tapping L, it goes faster.

125
00:06:38.920 --> 00:06:45.083
If I tap J several times,
it'll go backward faster.

126
00:06:45.083 --> 00:06:46.050
And then here's the other one.

127
00:06:46.050 --> 00:06:50.300
If I hold K and hold L,
it goes forward very slowly.

128
00:06:51.970 --> 00:06:56.910
If I hold K and hold J,
it goes backward very slowly.

129
00:06:56.910 --> 00:06:58.521
>> That can be really handy I can say.

130
00:06:58.521 --> 00:07:01.880
>> Yeah, so
you don't have to use your mouse so much.

131
00:07:01.880 --> 00:07:06.960
You can use your mouse on the things that
you really want to use your mouse with.

132
00:07:06.960 --> 00:07:11.719
Now, what part of this do
I want is the question.

133
00:07:11.719 --> 00:07:17.254
Because I don't want all
of just Seymour doing this,

134
00:07:17.254 --> 00:07:21.807
or maybe I want segments of Seymour, okay.

135
00:07:21.807 --> 00:07:24.796
Now there's a lot of
different ways to do this.

136
00:07:24.796 --> 00:07:31.161
Some people feel very comfortable doing
what's called the subclip method.

137
00:07:31.161 --> 00:07:35.028
A lot of people that might be doing
documentaries or you just roll your

138
00:07:35.028 --> 00:07:39.550
camera, you might say I wish I had a lot
of little clips of this big thing.

139
00:07:39.550 --> 00:07:41.520
This is sort of an organizational thing.

140
00:07:41.520 --> 00:07:43.200
You don't have to do this.

141
00:07:43.200 --> 00:07:45.980
I'm going to do it a different
way with another clip later.

142
00:07:45.980 --> 00:07:50.935
But what I can do is down here,
in this bar,

143
00:07:50.935 --> 00:07:57.286
I have all these different
tools that I can use in here.

144
00:07:57.286 --> 00:08:01.045
One is called Mark In and
one is called Mark Out.

145
00:08:01.045 --> 00:08:07.322
And what I'm doing is I am defining a
segment That I want to use in my timeline.

146
00:08:07.322 --> 00:08:09.410
Cuz I'm not gonna use all of this.

147
00:08:09.410 --> 00:08:10.694
So let me just play forward with L.

148
00:08:12.434 --> 00:08:13.650
And I can do these on the fly.

149
00:08:13.650 --> 00:08:15.100
I can say I want that there.

150
00:08:16.896 --> 00:08:18.013
>> And you're clicking with
your mouse- [CROSSTALK]

151
00:08:18.013 --> 00:08:18.678
>> I'm just clicking with

152
00:08:18.678 --> 00:08:19.280
the mouse right now.

153
00:08:19.280 --> 00:08:20.220
And clicking that one.

154
00:08:20.220 --> 00:08:21.870
And then I'll pause it with K.

155
00:08:21.870 --> 00:08:23.915
>> Okay, as you're going through,
as it's playing,

156
00:08:23.915 --> 00:08:26.850
you're like nope that's the exact in,
and that's the out.

157
00:08:26.850 --> 00:08:31.145
>> Right, if I wanted to be a strict
keyboard user, I could just hit i for

158
00:08:31.145 --> 00:08:32.190
in and O for out.

159
00:08:33.370 --> 00:08:35.390
>> Okay, so-
>> While you're using the j and the ks.

160
00:08:35.390 --> 00:08:37.260
>> Exactly,
because they're right above each other.

161
00:08:37.260 --> 00:08:38.370
They're right above that, okay?

162
00:08:38.370 --> 00:08:38.990
So, yeah.

163
00:08:38.990 --> 00:08:42.290
And then I can do something
else with the mouse.

164
00:08:42.290 --> 00:08:43.740
Now, I'd like to point this out,

165
00:08:43.740 --> 00:08:46.280
is where is this subclip
thing you're talking about?

166
00:08:46.280 --> 00:08:47.736
If I go to Help, and I go subclip.

167
00:08:49.686 --> 00:08:51.510
Make subclip, okay?

168
00:08:51.510 --> 00:08:53.100
This is a, under the menu bar.

169
00:08:53.100 --> 00:08:55.720
This is a clip item, okay?

170
00:08:55.720 --> 00:08:57.320
And it's also command+u.

171
00:08:57.320 --> 00:09:01.120
If something already has
a hot key attached to it,

172
00:09:01.120 --> 00:09:03.870
it's gonna be on the right, all right?

173
00:09:03.870 --> 00:09:05.095
So I can say make subclip.

174
00:09:05.095 --> 00:09:07.849
And I do that.

175
00:09:07.849 --> 00:09:08.950
Boom!

176
00:09:08.950 --> 00:09:11.270
All right,
it'll say what do you want it to be named?

177
00:09:11.270 --> 00:09:15.340
I'm gonna keep, honestly,
this is just my own little proclivity.

178
00:09:15.340 --> 00:09:21.000
I'm gonna say, okay, this is Seymore sees.

179
00:09:21.000 --> 00:09:21.500
Setmore?

180
00:09:22.500 --> 00:09:23.545
That's his twin brother.

181
00:09:23.545 --> 00:09:31.141
Seymore sees tomato, okay?

182
00:09:31.141 --> 00:09:35.960
Now, this has a thing called restrict
trims to subclip boundaries.

183
00:09:35.960 --> 00:09:40.450
For now, before we understand what trim
is, I'm going to keep that on, all right?

184
00:09:40.450 --> 00:09:41.480
But you don't have to.

185
00:09:41.480 --> 00:09:43.310
>> Is that like cropping?

186
00:09:43.310 --> 00:09:46.280
>> In a way,
you could say it's like cropping.

187
00:09:46.280 --> 00:09:49.949
And then what happens is,
it's down here, okay?

188
00:09:49.949 --> 00:09:51.356
It's right there.

189
00:09:51.356 --> 00:09:51.856
Seymore sees tomatoes.

190
00:09:53.542 --> 00:09:57.250
That's it, and it's a little suclip, okay?

191
00:09:57.250 --> 00:10:02.299
Basically, if I clicked that,
all right, let me zoom back.

192
00:10:02.299 --> 00:10:06.807
If I click that one, come here you,
let me do this, okay?

193
00:10:06.807 --> 00:10:10.308
And group settings, maximize that panel.

194
00:10:10.308 --> 00:10:12.343
Let me find that again, okay?

195
00:10:12.343 --> 00:10:13.121
Seymore sees tomato.

196
00:10:13.121 --> 00:10:15.162
Give it a double-click, and
it's gonna pop it up into there.

197
00:10:18.170 --> 00:10:22.490
Notice it's only as much
as I marked in that area.

198
00:10:22.490 --> 00:10:23.250
It's nothing else.

199
00:10:24.890 --> 00:10:25.610
Nothing else.

200
00:10:25.610 --> 00:10:27.430
So I could do this to the whole clip.

201
00:10:27.430 --> 00:10:28.366
Let me just find 0078.

202
00:10:28.366 --> 00:10:32.907
I could go back and
do this multiple times, and

203
00:10:32.907 --> 00:10:37.780
just pull all the little
subparts that I want.

204
00:10:37.780 --> 00:10:40.940
Now if I keep doing that, let me,
I can even go back into here and

205
00:10:40.940 --> 00:10:42.030
get a little bit of this part.

206
00:10:42.030 --> 00:10:43.780
And I just hit I.

207
00:10:43.780 --> 00:10:44.280
And I'll hit L.

208
00:10:48.577 --> 00:10:51.140
Okay, boom, right after his reaction.

209
00:10:51.140 --> 00:10:54.550
Now, this is one of those things,
I'm gonna do this like nine times.

210
00:10:54.550 --> 00:10:58.890
So, why do I wanna keep going back
up here to, wait, was it sequence?

211
00:10:58.890 --> 00:10:59.640
Was it a marker?

Okay, the path means when I send
it where is it going to go.

453
00:23:25.053 --> 00:23:26.470
And then I can see.

454
00:23:26.470 --> 00:23:29.120
It takes me out to the finder and
where it will go.

455
00:23:31.390 --> 00:23:34.180
This last thing here I
want to show that's very,

456
00:23:34.180 --> 00:23:38.240
very convenient, it's Import into project.

457
00:23:38.240 --> 00:23:41.980
Let's say that I did want
to make a bunch of stills.

458
00:23:41.980 --> 00:23:44.550
Often something in it,
maybe create a montage.

459
00:23:45.800 --> 00:23:48.260
That means I have to bring
it back into the project.

460
00:23:48.260 --> 00:23:51.077
It used to be which you had to do,
you exported them then you had to go to

461
00:23:51.077 --> 00:23:53.183
the finder, find them again and
re-import them.

462
00:23:53.183 --> 00:23:57.399
This will just say and
I'm going to go ahead and do this,

463
00:23:57.399 --> 00:24:00.270
import it back into the project.

464
00:24:00.270 --> 00:24:01.167
Boom.

465
00:24:01.167 --> 00:24:03.148
And there it is.

466
00:24:03.148 --> 00:24:03.776
And this tells me, yeah.

467
00:24:03.776 --> 00:24:04.933
>> It's your still, okay.

468
00:24:04.933 --> 00:24:09.900
>> It tells me it's a still image,
boom, even has an alpha channel.

469
00:24:11.520 --> 00:24:14.062
Because of the way this camera works,

470
00:24:14.062 --> 00:24:17.642
it's gotta build an alpha channel,
so kinda crazy.

471
00:24:17.642 --> 00:24:18.452
>> That's handy, yeah.

472
00:24:18.452 --> 00:24:20.820
>> Yeah, it's very handy.

473
00:24:20.820 --> 00:24:22.380
Let me also show you something
about the proxy thing.

474
00:24:22.380 --> 00:24:26.760
If I did this with the proxy, and
I'm gonna give it a different name.

475
00:24:29.500 --> 00:24:30.690
There's my phone number, great.

476
00:24:32.340 --> 00:24:34.300
Cuz you know why it's on there?

477
00:24:34.300 --> 00:24:37.302
All of this metadata is
attached to the name.

478
00:24:37.302 --> 00:24:38.593
>> Cuz you took it on your phone.

479
00:24:38.593 --> 00:24:40.010
>> No, this isn't a black magic.

480
00:24:40.010 --> 00:24:43.180
I put it in the actual high end camera.

481
00:24:43.180 --> 00:24:45.782
And it did that, so it's all attached.

482
00:24:45.782 --> 00:24:49.015
I'm just gonna say O2,
Import back in the project > OK.

483
00:24:49.015 --> 00:24:53.150
It's the same thing.

484
00:24:53.150 --> 00:24:54.259
Notice it did it at the 1920x1080.

485
00:24:54.259 --> 00:24:57.820
It didn't do it at the proxy resolution.

486
00:24:57.820 --> 00:24:59.510
So a lot of people get scared of that.

487
00:24:59.510 --> 00:25:02.060
It's like, no, it's gonna do, yeah.

488
00:25:02.060 --> 00:25:03.310
So it didn't do the proxy resolution.

489
00:25:04.570 --> 00:25:07.360
>> It's the default from the master file,
the master clip.

490
00:25:07.360 --> 00:25:08.890
>> It's the default, yep, mm-hm, yep.

491
00:25:08.890 --> 00:25:09.794
So there you go.

492
00:25:09.794 --> 00:25:10.357
>> Nice.

493
00:25:10.357 --> 00:25:10.957
>> Fantastic.

494
00:25:10.957 --> 00:25:13.198
>> But that can be very confusing,
same icon.

495
00:25:13.198 --> 00:25:14.229
>> It can.

496
00:25:14.229 --> 00:25:17.271
>> But it does very different things,
it's similar.

497
00:25:17.271 --> 00:25:18.507
>> It does very different things, yeah.

498
00:25:18.507 --> 00:25:20.041
>> But it's different.

499
00:25:20.041 --> 00:25:26.190
>> So what we're going to do is
notice we're still on the right side.

500
00:25:26.190 --> 00:25:28.580
I'm going to take a segment of this.

501
00:25:30.620 --> 00:25:32.570
From here right when he looks up.

502
00:25:33.900 --> 00:25:34.939
>> Wait, we're on the left side, right?

503
00:25:34.939 --> 00:25:35.860
>> Yeah, we're on the left side.

504
00:25:35.860 --> 00:25:36.438
>> Okay, sorry.

505
00:25:36.438 --> 00:25:38.295
[LAUGH]
>> I know, no, I do that all the time.

506
00:25:38.295 --> 00:25:41.556
>> [LAUGH] I'm just making sure cuz
I'm one of those like, okay, wait,

507
00:25:41.556 --> 00:25:42.545
what side are we on?

508
00:25:42.545 --> 00:25:43.570
>> We're on the left side.

509
00:25:43.570 --> 00:25:44.684
No, I do that all the time sorry, okay?

510
00:25:44.684 --> 00:25:47.830
[LAUGH]
>> Right versus correct, is that-

511
00:25:47.830 --> 00:25:53.620
>> Yeah, so right versus correct, so yeah.

512
00:25:53.620 --> 00:25:54.797
Yeah, cats.
[LAUGH]

513
00:25:54.797 --> 00:25:55.762
>> [LAUGH]

514
00:25:55.762 --> 00:25:56.833
>> So there we go.

515
00:25:56.833 --> 00:25:58.150
I screwed up.

516
00:25:58.150 --> 00:26:03.850
I wanted to hit O for out point,
but I hit I for in point.

517
00:26:03.850 --> 00:26:06.123
So what happens when things go wrong?

518
00:26:06.123 --> 00:26:08.489
Cmd+Z.

519
00:26:08.489 --> 00:26:10.304
>> Of course, Undo.

520
00:26:10.304 --> 00:26:13.069
>> Right, Undo, and
there's many levels of that.

521
00:26:13.069 --> 00:26:17.016
But there's another thing that you
are used to in Photoshop that is

522
00:26:17.016 --> 00:26:18.080
available here.

523
00:26:19.380 --> 00:26:20.713
There is a history.

524
00:26:20.713 --> 00:26:24.776
It's found in the project panel and
you can go back in the history as well.

525
00:26:24.776 --> 00:26:25.484
>> Nice, okay.
>> So yeah,

526
00:26:25.484 --> 00:26:30.285
that was specifically added because a lot
of people who aren't editors are going

527
00:26:30.285 --> 00:26:31.250
into this now.

528
00:26:31.250 --> 00:26:32.456
But they've worked in Photoshop.

529
00:26:32.456 --> 00:26:33.667
They've worked in Illustrator.

530
00:26:33.667 --> 00:26:35.631
And they've worked in other things like,
where's my history?

531
00:26:35.631 --> 00:26:36.867
>> So it wasn't always in there.

532
00:26:36.867 --> 00:26:39.490
>> No, so it's like where is my history?

533
00:26:39.490 --> 00:26:44.338
And all of us that made it was like,
yeah, that'd actually be great.

534
00:26:44.338 --> 00:26:47.400
>> Yeah [LAUGH]
>> So I'll drop an out point.

535
00:26:47.400 --> 00:26:48.530
I'm just gonna use O.

536
00:26:50.160 --> 00:26:51.202
Come here, O.

537
00:26:51.202 --> 00:26:53.303
Now over here,

538
00:26:56.174 --> 00:27:01.850
There's this thing called drop media
here to create sequence in the timeline.

539
00:27:01.850 --> 00:27:03.640
Just drop it there.

540
00:27:03.640 --> 00:27:06.264
This is the easiest form of an edit.

541
00:27:06.264 --> 00:27:10.543
And we're gonna get into more
elaborate ones in the next.

542
00:27:10.543 --> 00:27:13.516
But if I take this icon right here,

543
00:27:13.516 --> 00:27:18.757
the one that just says drag video,
and I drag it right there.

544
00:27:18.757 --> 00:27:25.400
Boom, I have created a sequence.

545
00:27:25.400 --> 00:27:27.265
And now what I'm using
in here are segments.

546
00:27:27.265 --> 00:27:29.570
Let me show you.

547
00:27:31.640 --> 00:27:33.580
There it is,
there's the little guy right there.

548
00:27:34.820 --> 00:27:35.680
Stretch it out.

549
00:27:35.680 --> 00:27:37.030
>> Now we're going to the right side.

550
00:27:37.030 --> 00:27:37.900
>> We're going to the right side.

551
00:27:37.900 --> 00:27:39.260
We're going from left to right.

552
00:27:39.260 --> 00:27:41.365
So we've made a magic transform,
I hate that word.

553
00:27:41.365 --> 00:27:41.970
>> [LAUGH]
>> But no,

554
00:27:41.970 --> 00:27:46.350
we've transformed it into a timeline.

555
00:27:46.350 --> 00:27:48.710
And this is what the audience
is going to see.

556
00:27:48.710 --> 00:27:50.760
And there it is right there.

557
00:27:50.760 --> 00:27:53.980
>> And you drag that from
the Source Monitor down into-

558
00:27:53.980 --> 00:27:55.850
>> Straight into the timeline.

559
00:27:55.850 --> 00:27:56.440
>> Okay.

560
00:27:56.440 --> 00:27:59.990
>> That's the simplest way to do it.

561
00:27:59.990 --> 00:28:05.510
There are many other methods that we're
gonna explore in the next lesson.

562
00:28:05.510 --> 00:28:10.690
But honestly, if I just do this,
I'm gonna resize this a little bit.

563
00:28:10.690 --> 00:28:13.289
And notice I can resize
this all over the place.

564
00:28:15.040 --> 00:28:17.480
Okay, squish, squish cuz I don't
really need anything out there.

565
00:28:17.480 --> 00:28:18.010
There it is.

566
00:28:18.010 --> 00:28:21.006
Now if I just move this
play head right there.

567
00:28:21.006 --> 00:28:22.857
And I go get another clip.

568
00:28:22.857 --> 00:28:26.760
Let's go get another one.

569
00:28:26.760 --> 00:28:27.770
There's Seymour again.

570
00:28:27.770 --> 00:28:29.580
He loves tomatoes.

571
00:28:29.580 --> 00:28:31.810
Go through there, boom.

572
00:28:31.810 --> 00:28:34.050
And then just drag that
right to the end of it.

573
00:28:35.330 --> 00:28:36.710
Boom, now I'm creating a movie.

574
00:28:37.840 --> 00:28:41.190
Boom, cat,
there's Seymour eating the tomato.

575
00:28:41.190 --> 00:28:42.600
Here's the interesting part.

576
00:28:42.600 --> 00:28:43.710
Why does that look so big?

577
00:28:45.850 --> 00:28:47.530
That doesn't look like that.

578
00:28:47.530 --> 00:28:48.250
>> It doesn't.

579
00:28:48.250 --> 00:28:51.750
>> So when we come back for the next
lesson, you're gonna find out why.

580
00:28:52.860 --> 00:28:54.250
Why I did this.

581
00:28:54.250 --> 00:28:55.810
How to make these changes.

582
00:28:55.810 --> 00:28:58.756
And when most people figure this out,

583
00:28:58.756 --> 00:29:03.910
what I can drag out of the center and
go here and get this crazy menu,

584
00:29:03.910 --> 00:29:08.750
they never go back to dragging
it straight to the timeline.

585
00:29:08.750 --> 00:29:10.390
>> Wow, I am very intrigued right now.

586
00:29:10.390 --> 00:29:12.523
[LAUGH]
>> And it's fun.

587
00:29:12.523 --> 00:29:13.231
It is fun.

588
00:29:13.231 --> 00:29:16.396
I do a lot of hotkey editing
because I work very fast.

589
00:29:16.396 --> 00:29:20.428
But I will tell you, there are times that
I will just sit there and I'll do this and

590
00:29:20.428 --> 00:29:21.820
I will be just as happy.

591
00:29:21.820 --> 00:29:24.015
>> Yeah [LAUGH]
>> I will be just as happy depending

592
00:29:24.015 --> 00:29:25.230
on what I'm working on.

593
00:29:25.230 --> 00:29:28.082
If I'm working on a narrative,
where I have two people in conversation,

594
00:29:28.082 --> 00:29:29.420
I'm probably gonna use hotkeys.

595
00:29:29.420 --> 00:29:32.490
But if I'm doing something where
it's like, wanna get this done,

596
00:29:32.490 --> 00:29:34.650
have a little fun with it,
I'm gonna do that drag this time.

597
00:29:34.650 --> 00:29:36.130
>> The drag and drop, wow.

598
00:29:36.130 --> 00:29:38.520
So the left to right,
we've been concentrating left.

599
00:29:38.520 --> 00:29:39.228
>> Left to right, yeah.

600
00:29:39.228 --> 00:29:41.390
>> I'm always equating it-
>> We're moving to the right, yeah.

601
00:29:41.390 --> 00:29:44.516
>> I'm equating it like a play,
like we're in the backstage.

602
00:29:44.516 --> 00:29:46.960
So the left hand side is
we're behind the scenes,

603
00:29:46.960 --> 00:29:49.530
we're behind the curtain,
getting the actors ready.

604
00:29:49.530 --> 00:29:52.771
And then we're taking the actors and say,
okay, I got you in your right costume and

605
00:29:52.771 --> 00:29:54.060
you're in the right place.

606
00:29:54.060 --> 00:29:55.810
Boom, put you out onto the stage.

607
00:29:55.810 --> 00:30:01.510
>> You're the actor behind the stage,
but on the stage, you're the character.

608
00:30:01.510 --> 00:30:02.542
And that's exactly it.

609
00:30:02.542 --> 00:30:04.045
It's what you just said.

610
00:30:04.045 --> 00:30:04.708
>> Okay, yeah, no,
that's fantastic, though.

611
00:30:04.708 --> 00:30:05.508
>> I'm just saying, yeah.

612
00:30:05.508 --> 00:30:07.098
>> So
we've got people on the Source Monitor.

613
00:30:07.098 --> 00:30:09.063
>> I'm just repeating what you
said just to try and look smart.

614
00:30:09.063 --> 00:30:11.388
>> Yeah [LAUGH]
>> I'm trying so hard.

615
00:30:11.388 --> 00:30:12.292
[LAUGH]
>> Well,

616
00:30:12.292 --> 00:30:14.440
just different correlations
to different people.

617
00:30:14.440 --> 00:30:15.989
>> Sure.
>> That's the way my brain's going.

618
00:30:15.989 --> 00:30:20.690
So I'm just making sure that I'm
on the right page with the script.

619
00:30:20.690 --> 00:30:23.940
So, all right, well, thank you so
much for explaining the Source Monitor.

620
00:30:23.940 --> 00:30:26.714
And I'm very curious as to where
we're going next with this timeline.

621
00:30:26.714 --> 00:30:29.678
And I don't wanna see the whole
Seymour and the tomatoes.

622
00:30:29.678 --> 00:30:32.507
And it looks like, Seymour is saying, hey,

623
00:30:32.507 --> 00:30:35.950
there's somebody eating
those tomatoes over there.

624
00:30:35.950 --> 00:30:36.896
>> Yeah.
>> I love it.

625
00:30:36.896 --> 00:30:38.621
>> See, we're gonna talk a little
bit about that editing theory

626
00:30:38.621 --> 00:30:39.340
when we come back.

627
00:30:39.340 --> 00:30:40.530
>> Awesome, well, I can't wait.

628
00:30:40.530 --> 00:30:43.409
So well then we'll go ahead and
sign off for this episode and

629
00:30:43.409 --> 00:30:45.665
we'll be coming back
with more very shortly.

630
00:30:45.665 --> 00:30:49.400
So, for right now, signing off for
CreativeProTV, I'm your host, Vonne Smith.

631
00:30:49.400 --> 00:30:50.390
>> And I'm Jim Biddle.

632
00:30:50.390 --> 00:30:51.123
>> And we'll see you soon.

633
00:30:51.123 --> 00:30:55.449
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: We begin creating our first edited story by adding clips to the timeline. James shows different ways to drag and drop into the timeline or the program panel as well as using keyboard shortcuts for adding clips to insert, overwrite, overlay, replace, and insert before/after into the sequence.
episodes.title: Our First Story
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.140 --> 00:00:06.721
[SOUND]

2
00:00:06.721 --> 00:00:11.233
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.233 --> 00:00:15.500
Hello, and welcome back to another
exciting edition of CreativeProTV.

4
00:00:15.500 --> 00:00:17.505
I'm your host Vonne Smith and

5
00:00:17.505 --> 00:00:21.441
we're continuing on with
our Adobe Premier CC 2016.

6
00:00:21.441 --> 00:00:23.927
Not 2016, it's 2017.

7
00:00:23.927 --> 00:00:26.237
See, I was catching myself.

8
00:00:26.237 --> 00:00:27.354
>> Yeah, you gotta catch yourself.

9
00:00:27.354 --> 00:00:30.423
>> Gotta keep on score that we're in 2017.

10
00:00:30.423 --> 00:00:31.660
That's the year we're in.

11
00:00:31.660 --> 00:00:36.402
[LAUGH] So here to help me keep
myself in check about what year we're

12
00:00:36.402 --> 00:00:38.870
actually in is Mr. Jim Biddle.

13
00:00:38.870 --> 00:00:39.910
Welcome back.

14
00:00:39.910 --> 00:00:41.540
>> I'm glad we're both here,

15
00:00:41.540 --> 00:00:45.850
cuz I'm gonna clear up some stuff that
I've done in the last few episodes.

16
00:00:45.850 --> 00:00:48.770
Because this happens, okay, it happens.

17
00:00:48.770 --> 00:00:51.060
Why?
Because you get to working with this and

18
00:00:51.060 --> 00:00:53.030
you get convinced of something,
you do this.

19
00:00:53.030 --> 00:00:55.052
Believe me,
I do this on purpose, actually.

20
00:00:55.052 --> 00:00:57.720
We're gonna go back to
the keyboard real quick.

21
00:00:57.720 --> 00:01:00.380
And I wanna show you something, okay?

22
00:01:00.380 --> 00:01:05.608
First of all,
notice I have the ability to say,

23
00:01:05.608 --> 00:01:11.244
what keyboard or
what command area am I looking at?

24
00:01:11.244 --> 00:01:14.743
So right now,
I'm looking at the entire application.

25
00:01:14.743 --> 00:01:20.195
But if I say, I'm going to look
at the Legacy Title Panel,

26
00:01:20.195 --> 00:01:26.580
that's where you say, oo,
L just doesn't mean shuttle right.

27
00:01:26.580 --> 00:01:29.970
In this panel, it means this.

28
00:01:29.970 --> 00:01:32.990
So that's where a lot
of people get confused.

29
00:01:32.990 --> 00:01:35.970
>> And that's when we were trying so
hard to look at all of those commands.

30
00:01:35.970 --> 00:01:39.310
We were looking for the L and
it's going through every single one.

31
00:01:39.310 --> 00:01:40.047
And we're trying all these arrays.

32
00:01:40.047 --> 00:01:40.691
>> Right.

33
00:01:40.691 --> 00:01:45.213
>> If we would've just went up there and
said, let's talk about the source monitor,

34
00:01:45.213 --> 00:01:46.259
then, okay.

35
00:01:46.259 --> 00:01:50.115
>> And the other thing was,
I got my symbols mixed up,

36
00:01:50.115 --> 00:01:52.276
which happens all the time.

37
00:01:52.276 --> 00:01:54.676
That is actually Shift.

38
00:01:54.676 --> 00:01:57.180
The arrow going up is Shift.

39
00:01:57.180 --> 00:01:58.330
So guess what?

40
00:01:59.660 --> 00:02:05.040
What was a bug at one point in Adobe,
isn't a bug anymore.

41
00:02:05.040 --> 00:02:07.207
>> It's Shift 1, 2, 3, 4 and all of that.

42
00:02:07.207 --> 00:02:08.753
I kept thinking Command.

43
00:02:08.753 --> 00:02:11.149
>> Okay I-
>> It was Shift.

44
00:02:11.149 --> 00:02:13.912
>> I'm a bilingual as I call it,
I'm Mac and PC.

45
00:02:13.912 --> 00:02:16.913
But there's so many times where
I was like, I can't remember,

46
00:02:16.913 --> 00:02:20.546
it's the little thing that looks like
this and there's little dots on it or-

47
00:02:20.546 --> 00:02:22.494
>> Exactly, and we all run into that.

48
00:02:22.494 --> 00:02:25.586
You're so convinced, and the thing
is I'm going off of muscle memory,

49
00:02:25.586 --> 00:02:28.184
I'm thinking I'm hitting Command and
I'm hitting Shift.

50
00:02:28.184 --> 00:02:30.136
And that's the thing,
it's like, I [INAUDIBLE].

51
00:02:30.136 --> 00:02:31.842
You're going to experience this.

52
00:02:31.842 --> 00:02:35.530
You're going to experience this that
you're doing things you're thinking it's

53
00:02:35.530 --> 00:02:38.310
this but
you already know it's the other thing.

54
00:02:38.310 --> 00:02:39.736
>> I do this.
I have a whole other

55
00:02:39.736 --> 00:02:44.565
layer where I'm actually in a virtual
machine on a Windows machine on my Mac.

56
00:02:44.565 --> 00:02:47.532
But then there's the Control and Command
that do different things and I'm like,

57
00:02:47.532 --> 00:02:48.485
wait whoops, wrong one.

58
00:02:48.485 --> 00:02:51.970

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne review different options for navigating in the timeline. James demonstrates how to work with linked clips and how to isolate video from audio. He also shows how to trim and edit audio tracks.
episodes.title: Navigating the Timeline

episodes.description: In this episode, we examine the presets and options for exporting a project in Premiere Pro, including the time tuner option. We also discuss the ripple trim tool for trimming clips in the timeline.
episodes.title: Simple Export

episodes.description: James shows off his fun gadgets for shooting video with a smart phone and how to add transitions to sequences. He reviews timeline options in Premiere Pro preferences, hotkeys for inserting clips for the source panel to the timeline, and options for working in the panels to modify transition settings.  James also covers how to manage panels and workspace presets as well as create custom workspaces.
episodes.title: Adding Transitions

>> Yup.
>> Because you're-

453
00:22:34.710 --> 00:22:36.270
>> It's a little jumpy it's like why I

454
00:22:36.270 --> 00:22:38.940
do render it, and the interesting
thing is it's just the return key

455
00:22:39.940 --> 00:22:40.590
>> Hit the Return key and

456
00:22:40.590 --> 00:22:41.780
it will start the render.

457
00:22:41.780 --> 00:22:44.930
So if I hit the Return key,
there you go, boom done.

458
00:22:44.930 --> 00:22:45.980
>> That's easy.

459
00:22:45.980 --> 00:22:47.900
>> Yeah, I mean it's no problem at all.

460
00:22:47.900 --> 00:22:49.610
Now what if I want to
adjust the cube spin?

461
00:22:50.990 --> 00:22:54.920
One way is I could double-click it,
and there's the duration time.

462
00:22:56.980 --> 00:23:01.090
And I could say,
let's go back to 30 seconds.

463
00:23:01.090 --> 00:23:04.500
>> Now, now its 30 seconds
long it needs to be rendered.

464
00:23:04.500 --> 00:23:07.890
This is why in many cases you don't
just jump straight into rendering

465
00:23:07.890 --> 00:23:09.290
every single time you see the red line or

466
00:23:09.290 --> 00:23:13.060
you are going to create a bunch of preview
files and that takes up some space.

467
00:23:13.060 --> 00:23:15.890
>> If your going to be doing
transitions between multiple

468
00:23:15.890 --> 00:23:16.790
sequences
>> Yeah

469
00:23:16.790 --> 00:23:18.010
>> or segments

470
00:23:18.010 --> 00:23:18.510
>> Right.

471
00:23:18.510 --> 00:23:20.519
>> or clips.
>> [CROSSTALK] You're gonna need to

472
00:23:20.519 --> 00:23:22.236
make sure you do it at the very end.

473
00:23:22.236 --> 00:23:24.410
>> Right, or you be like me.

474
00:23:24.410 --> 00:23:25.280
Yeah, I made a bunch of previews.

475
00:23:25.280 --> 00:23:27.610
I'm gonna clear them out and redoing them.

476
00:23:27.610 --> 00:23:28.950
>> Cuz rendering can
take some time sometimes.

477
00:23:28.950 --> 00:23:30.510
>> They can take some time.

478
00:23:30.510 --> 00:23:35.829
The other thing I can do is if I highlight
it, I could go to Effects Controls.

479
00:23:37.640 --> 00:23:42.070
And it gives me a menu
of what I need to do.

480
00:23:43.830 --> 00:23:45.200
And it gives me star previews.

481
00:23:45.200 --> 00:23:47.090
Image A and it's like all this.

482
00:23:47.090 --> 00:23:49.818
Image A spins to reveal image B.

483
00:23:49.818 --> 00:23:51.130
Mathtitude faces of a cube.

484
00:23:51.130 --> 00:23:55.255
And you say to yourself,
I'm having a hard time understanding that.

485
00:23:55.255 --> 00:23:56.930
Show me the actual sources.

486
00:23:58.210 --> 00:24:02.540
And you can adjust its time,
you can also adjust how it spins.

487
00:24:03.600 --> 00:24:07.770
Like right now, it'll say west to east,
east to west, I can say south to north.

488
00:24:08.830 --> 00:24:14.110
So now it does it that way, or it does
it east to west, or north to south.

489
00:24:14.110 --> 00:24:18.160
And I can completely adjust how
I want this cube spin to happen.

490
00:24:20.456 --> 00:24:23.370
Now I don't have to do the default, okay?

491
00:24:23.370 --> 00:24:28.520
I don't have to do the default cube spin,
I could simply click it, delete it.

492
00:24:28.520 --> 00:24:30.680
I can come over here
to the transitions and

493
00:24:30.680 --> 00:24:34.350
say, you know what,
give me a film dissolve.

494
00:24:34.350 --> 00:24:38.810
Click it, drag it right on top,
and let go, and

495
00:24:38.810 --> 00:24:42.690
of course the default duration is 15.

496
00:24:42.690 --> 00:24:45.280
What most people don't understand,

497
00:24:46.290 --> 00:24:52.210
is if you go back to Preferences and
in this case Timeline.

498
00:24:52.210 --> 00:25:00.430
And if I change this to 35 frames,
nothing in the timeline changes.

499
00:25:01.930 --> 00:25:05.150
It will not change all of my times

500
00:25:05.150 --> 00:25:09.980
that I've already set on transitions
in the timeline, it doesn't do that.

501
00:25:09.980 --> 00:25:12.930
>> Cuz they're already on
the stage as I'm referring to it.

502
00:25:12.930 --> 00:25:15.240
>> Everything from here on out.

503
00:25:15.240 --> 00:25:16.890
>> Out, yeah.
>> Will be 35 frames,

504
00:25:16.890 --> 00:25:22.440
everything from here on out will be 35
frames, so it's easy to really do that.

505
00:25:22.440 --> 00:25:26.740
Now here's a little trick,
let's say somebody says,

506
00:25:26.740 --> 00:25:29.090
dissolves are great, I love dissolves.

507
00:25:29.090 --> 00:25:33.960
It's like, okay, terrific,
we'll make this large, okay.

508
00:25:33.960 --> 00:25:39.720
And so, if I highlight both of these and
then hit Cmd+D,

509
00:25:39.720 --> 00:25:43.570
because all the segments are highlighted,

510
00:25:43.570 --> 00:25:48.060
it finds every single cut and
puts a transition there.

511
00:25:48.060 --> 00:25:50.530
>> Yes, cuz Cmd+D was applied transition.

512
00:25:50.530 --> 00:25:51.060
>> Exactly.
>> And

513
00:25:51.060 --> 00:25:53.220
applied everything it said,
in, out, in, out.

514
00:25:53.220 --> 00:25:57.020
>> In, out, in, out, and so now it's
doing it on every single transition.

515
00:25:57.020 --> 00:26:01.274
Please don't do this [LAUGH] after awhile
it's kinda like, please don't do this.

516
00:26:01.274 --> 00:26:02.740
>> [LAUGH]
>> Please don't do this.

517
00:26:02.740 --> 00:26:05.716
>> Yeah, this is like the slide
transitions in PowerPoint,

518
00:26:05.716 --> 00:26:09.662
it's like you can do one, and if you
keep going, everyone's gonna be like,

519
00:26:09.662 --> 00:26:11.199
I'm getting sick right now.

520
00:26:11.199 --> 00:26:12.230
[LAUGH]
>> Or the thing is,

521
00:26:12.230 --> 00:26:14.020
if you put a dissolve on every cut,

522
00:26:14.020 --> 00:26:17.570
that means your ten second
video just took two years.

523
00:26:17.570 --> 00:26:21.590
Cuz it's like, it's a time and
it's like, okay goodnight, but yeah.

524
00:26:21.590 --> 00:26:25.120
So this is editing transitions,
and transitions are real fun,

525
00:26:25.120 --> 00:26:27.660
they're really easy, and
they're very easy to manipulate.

526
00:26:27.660 --> 00:26:31.670
So yeah they can step up what
you're doing quite a bit.

527
00:26:31.670 --> 00:26:33.440
>> And
they have a nice library obviously and

528
00:26:33.440 --> 00:26:36.910
for different reasons why you
might wanna use the cube one.

529
00:26:36.910 --> 00:26:38.490
And what is your audience and

530
00:26:38.490 --> 00:26:41.060
that kind of whole idea about why
I'd wanna pick this particular one.

531
00:26:41.060 --> 00:26:42.310
>> And the other thing about transitions,

532
00:26:42.310 --> 00:26:45.420
when you talk to somebody that
wants to you add transitions.

533
00:26:45.420 --> 00:26:48.770
Tell them every time you add
a transition like a dissolve or

534
00:26:48.770 --> 00:26:52.735
cube spin you are absolutely
drawing attention to the change.

535
00:26:52.735 --> 00:26:58.740
It's like there's a change happening here
and I want you to specifically see it.

536
00:26:58.740 --> 00:27:01.210
Sometimes in editing we want
it to be invisible, but

537
00:27:01.210 --> 00:27:03.580
this is very much, here it is.

538
00:27:03.580 --> 00:27:08.330
Cube spin, whatever, I want you to
know there is a change happening.

539
00:27:08.330 --> 00:27:12.630
>> Right, yeah, well speaking of changes
it looks like we're out of time for

540
00:27:12.630 --> 00:27:13.940
this particular episode.

541
00:27:13.940 --> 00:27:16.360
So we're gonna transition out, and

542
00:27:16.360 --> 00:27:19.020
go ahead [LAUGH] did you
see what I did there?

543
00:27:19.020 --> 00:27:20.090
>> I did, I did see what you did.

544
00:27:20.090 --> 00:27:20.960
>> That was my cube spin.

545
00:27:20.960 --> 00:27:21.850
>> I love it, I love it.

546
00:27:21.850 --> 00:27:23.220
>> [LAUGH] yes.
>> Your cube spinning out.

547
00:27:23.220 --> 00:27:27.260
>> Well it was a lot of great information
and I'm super excited to see what's next.

548
00:27:27.260 --> 00:27:28.750
>> Cool.
>> But for now, we're gonna go ahead and

549
00:27:28.750 --> 00:27:29.950
sign off for CreativeProTV,

550
00:27:29.950 --> 00:27:32.504
I've been your host Vonne Smith
>> I'm James Biddle.

551
00:27:32.504 --> 00:27:34.300
>> And we'll see you soon.

552
00:27:34.300 --> 00:27:38.667
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne discuss trimming techniques using hotkeys, editing in trim mode, the importance of the K key, and playback options in the preferences.
episodes.title: Simple Trimming
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.462
[SOUND]

2
00:00:06.462 --> 00:00:11.109
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.109 --> 00:00:15.057
Hello everyone, and welcome to another
exciting edition of CreativeProTV.

4
00:00:15.057 --> 00:00:19.795
I'm your host Vonne Smith and
we're continuing on with our series for

5
00:00:19.795 --> 00:00:22.054
Adobe Premiere Pro CC 2017.

6
00:00:22.054 --> 00:00:25.847
And in the studios with us yet
again is our amazing James Biddle.

7
00:00:25.847 --> 00:00:26.939
So glad to have you back.

8
00:00:26.939 --> 00:00:28.849
>> I appreciate the fact that you tried
to throw me out though, Saturday.

9
00:00:28.849 --> 00:00:32.145
>> [LAUGH] Well,
we had to bring you back because-

10
00:00:32.145 --> 00:00:32.838
>> I know, okay.

11
00:00:32.838 --> 00:00:34.406
>> We have to talk about trimming and
some other things, so-

12
00:00:34.406 --> 00:00:35.580
>> Yes, yes.

13
00:00:35.580 --> 00:00:37.748
A lot of people,
when they get into editing,

14
00:00:37.748 --> 00:00:41.185
they may talk to editors like myself
that have done this for a long time.

15
00:00:41.185 --> 00:00:44.840
They'll be talking about, well,
it's all the trimming is the art.

16
00:00:44.840 --> 00:00:47.444
And it's like, it is, but
it's very off putting.

17
00:00:47.444 --> 00:00:49.168
[LAUGH] We were like, I'm scared.

18
00:00:49.168 --> 00:00:52.060
>> [LAUGH]
>> And it's like, you're awful.

19
00:00:52.060 --> 00:00:53.150
But I don't blame you.

20
00:00:53.150 --> 00:00:53.850
So this one,

21
00:00:53.850 --> 00:00:58.930
we're gonna go really in depth in how to
tighten up what you got in your sequence,

22
00:00:58.930 --> 00:01:04.040
and feel comfortable doing it with
either the mouse, or with your hands.

23
00:01:04.040 --> 00:01:06.344
So we're going back to
the watermelon shot, okay.

24
00:01:06.344 --> 00:01:11.187
Now, in the watermelon shot
I'm looking for things.

25
00:01:11.187 --> 00:01:15.208
If you wanna get into film theory,
I'm looking for movement.

26
00:01:15.208 --> 00:01:18.320
I'm looking for movement,
I'm just gonna hit L and move forward.

27
00:01:19.620 --> 00:01:20.551
And there I have, yeah.

28
00:01:20.551 --> 00:01:22.160
I mean, yep, that is movement, I know.

29
00:01:22.160 --> 00:01:26.972
But then I do this thing with my finger,
I tap it with my finger.

30
00:01:26.972 --> 00:01:28.823
And then I'm going to
hit the Down Arrow Key,

31
00:01:28.823 --> 00:01:31.130
which is going to take
me to the next edit.

32
00:01:31.130 --> 00:01:34.160
And move forward, and
yeah, I've got motion but

33
00:01:34.160 --> 00:01:36.380
the big motion is right
there at the knife.

34
00:01:37.600 --> 00:01:41.740
So I'm thinking to myself, can I connect
the finger movement to the knife to

35
00:01:41.740 --> 00:01:46.320
make this a little bit more dynamic and
quote unquote, invisible.

36
00:01:46.320 --> 00:01:48.950
I'm connecting two different motions.

37
00:01:48.950 --> 00:01:55.120
Now here's one way to do this, and
I absolutely love this in Adobe.

38
00:01:55.120 --> 00:01:58.652
So I hit L, move forward.

39
00:01:58.652 --> 00:02:00.600
Now it's not gonna be super precise.

40
00:02:00.600 --> 00:02:03.879
I'm not looking for
super precise right now.

41
00:02:03.879 --> 00:02:07.836
Right there on that motion,
I'm gonna hit just one key, and

42
00:02:07.836 --> 00:02:09.630
it's going to be the W key.

43
00:02:11.310 --> 00:02:14.644
And what's gonna happen is this, okay?

44
00:02:14.644 --> 00:02:18.474
It's going to, and this is [LAUGH]
this is the way Adobe says it.

45
00:02:18.474 --> 00:02:21.210
It's really funny,
I love the way they name things.

46
00:02:21.210 --> 00:02:27.520
It's going to Ripple Trim from
the play head to the next edit.

47
00:02:29.310 --> 00:02:31.670
Or as I like to say, get rid of that.

48
00:02:31.670 --> 00:02:34.725
Get rid of everything from there to there,
okay?

49
00:02:34.725 --> 00:02:36.955
And that is W.

50
00:02:36.955 --> 00:02:39.269
>> How come they fancy
up a really simple like-

51
00:02:39.269 --> 00:02:41.051
>> Well, [CROSSTALK] technically

52
00:02:41.051 --> 00:02:44.069
they're being absolutely
precise in what it does.

53
00:02:44.069 --> 00:02:47.046
They're being absolutely precise, where
me it's like, eh, let's get rid of that.

54
00:02:47.046 --> 00:02:50.510
[LAUGH] It's like-
>> But it's those technical terminology

55
00:02:50.510 --> 00:02:54.370
within a specific application
of using all those big words-

56
00:02:54.370 --> 00:02:54.999
>> Right.

57
00:02:54.999 --> 00:02:56.916
>> That that's what they
are technically called.

58
00:02:56.916 --> 00:02:59.340
>> Right, cuz what most people do,
is they'd take the Blade Tool,

59
00:02:59.340 --> 00:03:01.826
they'd make a cut, and
then they'd highlight the piece of this.

60
00:03:01.826 --> 00:03:04.010
Let me demonstrate what
most people would do.

61
00:03:04.010 --> 00:03:07.020
Okay, so I'll go forward now, and

62
00:03:07.020 --> 00:03:10.080
what I wanna do is kinda connect
it to the cutting of the knife.

63
00:03:10.080 --> 00:03:13.676
I want it in a little bit, okay,
right before that little snap.

64
00:03:13.676 --> 00:03:18.181
And again, I can hold down K and
tap J and go back a frame at a time.

65
00:03:18.181 --> 00:03:22.080
So right about there is
what I'm looking for.

66
00:03:22.080 --> 00:03:24.232
Now most people would do this,
they would go over here.

67
00:03:24.232 --> 00:03:26.370
They would get their favorite friend,
the razor tool.

68
00:03:26.370 --> 00:03:27.720
They'd cut along here.

69
00:03:28.940 --> 00:03:31.880
And then they're cutting.

70
00:03:31.880 --> 00:03:33.150
And then let's make sure.

71
00:03:33.150 --> 00:03:36.476
I forgot to do the thing where
I made sure they were linked.

72
00:03:36.476 --> 00:03:37.617
And I'll cut it again.

73
00:03:37.617 --> 00:03:39.580
And then I'll come over here and get this.

74
00:03:39.580 --> 00:03:44.410
And then I'll hit Delete, and then
I'll pick it up and I'll move it here.

75
00:03:44.410 --> 00:03:46.040
And that took forever.

76
00:03:46.040 --> 00:03:47.894
So let me Cmd+Z back.

77
00:03:47.894 --> 00:03:51.957
>> So all of those steps that you just
did, with the cut and the delete and

78
00:03:51.957 --> 00:03:54.915
the move,
is all done with the Ripple something.

79
00:03:54.915 --> 00:03:56.522
[LAUGH]
>> Now in this case,

80
00:03:56.522 --> 00:04:02.376
the one on the opposite, the letter on
the opposite side of W on the keypad is Q,

81
00:04:02.376 --> 00:04:06.630
and that is ripple trim from
play head to previous edit.

82
00:04:06.630 --> 00:04:07.637
So now, this is the previous edit.

83
00:04:07.637 --> 00:04:09.227
>> Yes, yes,
that's what you said, that thing.

84
00:04:09.227 --> 00:04:11.810
>> That's the one, and then I just go Q.

85
00:04:11.810 --> 00:04:15.730
And everything that took me all
those steps, I just did in one.

86
00:04:15.730 --> 00:04:20.652
>> So W is forward, Q is-
>> Well,

87
00:04:20.652 --> 00:04:24.809
so let's take a look at
the play head here, okay.

88
00:04:24.809 --> 00:04:26.725
Yes, W-
>> From the play head I get-

89
00:04:26.725 --> 00:04:28.861
>> From the play head to the next

90
00:04:28.861 --> 00:04:30.520
edit is W.

91
00:04:30.520 --> 00:04:32.950
From the play head to
the previous edit is Q.

92
00:04:32.950 --> 00:04:36.800
>> Yeah, and I guess in my brain forward
on the timeline, backward on the timeline.

93
00:04:36.800 --> 00:04:41.689
>> Exactly, the term that we
actually use is downstream.

94
00:04:41.689 --> 00:04:46.210
If we are going from left to
right were going downstream.

95
00:04:46.210 --> 00:04:49.642
If we're going right to left, upstream.

96
00:04:49.642 --> 00:04:53.820
And most of what we do when we
create a sequence is go downstream.

97
00:04:53.820 --> 00:04:58.869
So now lets a look at this, there it is.

98
00:04:58.869 --> 00:05:02.325
I always wanna do a Werner Herzog
when I'm looking at my own work.

99
00:05:02.325 --> 00:05:03.669
It's lovely.

100
00:05:03.669 --> 00:05:08.098
See, so now,
it does not know that it is going to be

101
00:05:08.098 --> 00:05:11.271
killed in the bright, bright sun.

102
00:05:11.271 --> 00:05:14.504
>> [LAUGH]
>> Not knowing that one single tap

103
00:05:14.504 --> 00:05:16.670
will lead to its demise.

104
00:05:16.670 --> 00:05:19.547
And that's the thing, that's a trim,

105
00:05:19.547 --> 00:05:23.280
is I cut two actions that
are completely different.

106
00:05:23.280 --> 00:05:25.270
Tapping on it and
cutting it, two different.

107
00:05:25.270 --> 00:05:28.460
But it makes it, I don't know, we're
gonna talk about color correction later.

108
00:05:28.460 --> 00:05:34.042
But it makes it seamless, it doesn't
draw attention to it like a transition.

109
00:05:34.042 --> 00:05:34.930
Okay, it doesn't.

110
00:05:34.930 --> 00:05:36.419
It's like all of a sudden,
boom, there it is.

111
00:05:37.570 --> 00:05:40.780
And this is a great technique.

112
00:05:40.780 --> 00:05:45.360
Now somebody like me,
I might say, not enough frames.

113
00:05:45.360 --> 00:05:49.088
I really wanna get that connection
in there and you do this a lot when

114
00:05:49.088 --> 00:05:52.810
you work with actors and
reaction shots and timing on that.

115
00:05:52.810 --> 00:06:00.840
So here's how we can do that either
with a mouse or with hot keys, okay.

116
00:06:00.840 --> 00:06:05.590
We go into what is called trimming mode,
and it's really easy.

117
00:06:05.590 --> 00:06:07.130
Think about it this way.

118
00:06:07.130 --> 00:06:11.810
Right now you're in editing mode,
you would like to shift to trim mode.

119
00:06:11.810 --> 00:06:14.768
So if I hold down the Shift key and hit T,

120
00:06:14.768 --> 00:06:18.007
I am now in what is called trim mode,
okay?

121
00:06:18.007 --> 00:06:22.561
And I have what's known as a rolling edit,
all right?

122
00:06:22.561 --> 00:06:27.479
Let me squeeze that up a little bit, cool.

123
00:06:27.479 --> 00:06:29.750
I have what's called a rolling edit.

124
00:06:29.750 --> 00:06:34.050
And what is happening is it's showing me,
sometimes when you zoom it up,

125
00:06:34.050 --> 00:06:35.060
it happens like this.

126
00:06:35.060 --> 00:06:39.275
It's showing me this side,
okay, often called the A side.

127
00:06:39.275 --> 00:06:40.572
And it's showing me the B side.

128
00:06:40.572 --> 00:06:42.443
So this is where they connect.

129
