00:19:19.606 --> 00:19:24.007
If I hold down K and tap J, it trims.

357
00:19:24.007 --> 00:19:25.431
>> Cuz we're in trim mode?

358
00:19:25.431 --> 00:19:29.060
>> Right, so technically then
you're saying, wait a minute.

359
00:19:29.060 --> 00:19:31.790
So if I just tap J it trims in real time?

360
00:19:31.790 --> 00:19:33.200
Yes, it does.

361
00:19:33.200 --> 00:19:36.814
So I can say, [SOUND] right there.

362
00:19:36.814 --> 00:19:38.350
>> Wow.
>> Boom, and then I can just do.

363
00:19:39.470 --> 00:19:44.090
So I know a lot of people,
instead of doing the option,

364
00:19:44.090 --> 00:19:48.216
left, right, all that, they just go J-K-L.

365
00:19:48.216 --> 00:19:49.189
If you're in trim mode.

366
00:19:49.189 --> 00:19:51.629
>> If you're in trim mode.
>> Cuz J-K-L in the other place that we

367
00:19:51.629 --> 00:19:53.901
were at [LAUGH] means something different.

368
00:19:53.901 --> 00:19:55.140
>> Right and I'll just Ctrl+T.

369
00:19:55.140 --> 00:20:01.410
That's why that panel thing in the keys
is really, in the keyboard settings.

370
00:20:01.410 --> 00:20:03.795
That's why going to
the different panels and

371
00:20:03.795 --> 00:20:06.944
seeing that It means different
stuff in different panels.

372
00:20:06.944 --> 00:20:10.939
>> This is really kind of coming full
circle to me right now, the okay,

373
00:20:10.939 --> 00:20:13.160
I see what you're putting down.

374
00:20:13.160 --> 00:20:16.500
>> Right, so there's all kinds of ways to
do it like boom, here I go, then boom.

375
00:20:16.500 --> 00:20:18.440
All right, so now I'm happy with it.

376
00:20:18.440 --> 00:20:19.803
And this is what editors do.

377
00:20:19.803 --> 00:20:23.569
We sit there and we sit there and
we go, one frame, no, two frames,

378
00:20:23.569 --> 00:20:25.240
no, one frame, two frames.

379

And then everybody's banging
their heads on the table.

00:20:28.014 --> 00:20:30.127
Yeah, so there is a method.

381

There's many different methods to trim,
pick one that you like.

382
00:20:34.770 --> 00:20:38.840
Because it's not good to like razor,
remove,

383
00:20:38.840 --> 00:20:40.790
or send it back to the source monitor.

384
00:20:40.790 --> 00:20:42.510
Try and do it there and load it back.

385
00:20:42.510 --> 00:20:46.220
Work, when you've got stuff,
is your sequence in your timeline?

386
00:20:46.220 --> 00:20:48.830
Work in your timeline, okay?

387
00:20:48.830 --> 00:20:51.280
I know it's frustrating and
scary at the beginning.

388
00:20:51.280 --> 00:20:55.490
But when you do, you'll go a lot faster,
you'll feel more confident in how you

00:20:55.490 --> 00:20:59.160
create your story, and
it will just be a lot better.

390
00:20:59.160 --> 00:21:01.640
This is a great thing to practice

then add four shots, and
then add five shots, and yeah.

>> Yeah, it's the whole learn

But then if you can walk really good

then yeah,
it's gonna save a huge amount of time.

395
00:21:13.248 --> 00:21:13.927
>> It really is.

396

>> I like where you're saying,
pick one way and stick with it.

Because that's the one that you're
going to get super proficient in and

398
00:21:20.511 --> 00:21:25.254
be able to do all this edits really
quickly and really know what you're doing

399
00:21:25.254 --> 00:21:25.823
>> There you go.

400
00:21:25.823 --> 00:21:29.280
>> Wow, that was fascinating so
>> Well, I'm glad you enjoyed it.

401
00:21:29.280 --> 00:21:30.260
>> I really enjoyed it.

402

And I hope all of you all out

But it is that time to go ahead and

We're not doing trim.
We're gonna trim this out,

I don't know from using this

406
00:21:40.284 --> 00:21:43.655
>> I'm gonna trim my head to face

>> [LAUGH] And for

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne discuss the reasons how to replace footage from the project panel, interpret footage for speed effects, snapping of the playhead in the preferences, match frame for creating effects, and effects parameters in the effects panel.
episodes.title: Adding Effects
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:06.455
[NOISE]

2

>> Hello, everyone, and

with Adobe Premier Pro CC2017.

7

And back in the studio to help us yet

8
00:00:26.280 --> 00:00:28.310
Hi.
>> Hey, it's good to see you again.

9
00:00:28.310 --> 00:00:29.210

>> Hey,

11

>> No, it's not.

12

Not at all.

13
00:00:34.580 --> 00:00:35.285
My goodness.

14
00:00:35.285 --> 00:00:38.285
>> Well, I hear we're going
to be adding effects, so.

15
00:00:38.285 --> 00:00:39.775
>> Yeah,
we're going to start adding effects.

16

And usually what happens is people think

And that if you keep with a simple plan,

In many cases,

>> Is this kinda one of those
like less is more type things?

24
00:01:05.440 --> 00:01:08.160
There's probably lots of them, but
you might not wanna go too crazy.

25
00:01:09.160 --> 00:01:11.596
Okay, good.
>> All right, so first of all,

27

28

>> The other left.
>> [CROSSTALK]

29

So we're going back to the left side,

which is going to involve

>> I don't think it's that bad [CROSSTALK]

40

But as you notice,
I have put it in here three times.

Cuz it's Watermelon 2016.

Well, it's not 2016, it's 2017.

So what can I do to change this,

Now what?

You can actually work, and I'm using this

00:02:10.415 --> 00:02:14.515
You can work on the left side to make very
simple changes, cuz the first thing you

And notice, the 2017 is now in Comic Sans,

A personal war against people and

71

I can actually do that with video files.

Occasionally, you might get this like,
okay,

we don't have this shot yet.

It's like, okay, just put in a dummy shot,

If I had any kind of graphic element on

I did any color correction around that,

78
00:03:43.623 --> 00:03:48.329
By replacing that source,
by basically pointing the clip,

the master clip,
from one piece of media to another, okay?

80
00:03:53.052 --> 00:03:56.350
That's all I'm doing,
I'm just rerouting the train, so to speak.

81
00:03:56.350 --> 00:03:57.430
I could keep all of my,

any elements that are in there that
are like I'm gonna go over the key frames.

83
00:04:02.890 --> 00:04:03.630
One other thing.

I talked about this a little earlier.

85

86
00:04:07.735 --> 00:04:10.075
And look, it's called watermelon.

87
00:04:10.075 --> 00:04:10.985
Let's bring this up.

88
00:04:10.985 --> 00:04:15.208
Gonna use that tilde accent grave key.

89
00:04:15.208 --> 00:04:21.387
Now, remember how I said this
one is technically 24 frames.

00:04:21.387 --> 00:04:22.925
I'm just gonna use 24 and 60, okay?

91
00:04:22.925 --> 00:04:23.942
This one's 24.

92
00:04:23.942 --> 00:04:25.884
This one's 60.

93
00:04:25.884 --> 00:04:30.287
The sequence is 24, okay?

94
00:04:30.287 --> 00:04:33.539
So a lot of people when they say, they say
hey, how can you put those in there and

00:04:33.539 --> 00:04:35.805
they both kinda look the same,
they both look normal,

96
00:04:35.805 --> 00:04:38.050

97
00:04:38.050 --> 00:04:42.010
If you do it this way,
we call it a mixed media sequence,

98
00:04:42.010 --> 00:04:47.120
you can put different resolutions and
different frame rates in the sequence and

99
00:04:47.120 --> 00:04:50.900
it will conform and
it will just make it work, okay?

100
00:04:50.900 --> 00:04:52.450
What if I didn't want to do that?

101
00:04:53.680 --> 00:04:57.540
I did this for a specific reason, okay?

102
00:04:57.540 --> 00:05:02.543
I did it, I shot this at 60 for

103
00:05:02.543 --> 00:05:05.100
And I used,
I wonder which one of these I used.

104
00:05:05.100 --> 00:05:07.120
I used the watermelon shot, Okay?

105
00:05:09.050 --> 00:05:11.290
This is a kind of like an effect.

00:05:11.290 --> 00:05:14.250
Most people, when they do a speed effect,

00:05:14.250 --> 00:05:18.460
another time, they adjust

108
00:05:19.630 --> 00:05:21.940
But what I'm going to do is this.

109
00:05:21.940 --> 00:05:23.060
I'm going to ctrl+click.

110
00:05:23.060 --> 00:05:25.320
I have an option called modify.

111
00:05:26.960 --> 00:05:28.600
And if I click the wrong one, I am, oops,

112
00:05:28.600 --> 00:05:32.160
it's not audio channels, well,
I can go through the tabs, okay?

113
00:05:32.160 --> 00:05:36.979
I have the ability to modify audio

114
00:05:36.979 --> 00:05:42.207
we can go over briefly in audio, which
is sometimes you have a dead channel,

115
00:05:42.207 --> 00:05:44.431
there's nothing in the right.

116
00:05:44.431 --> 00:05:48.302
So you wish you had two lefts.

117
00:05:48.302 --> 00:05:49.550
And now I have two lefts.

118
00:05:49.550 --> 00:05:52.134
Cuz we're gonna talk about
tracks versus clips.

119
00:05:52.134 --> 00:05:53.740
We're not going to worry
about that right now..

120
00:05:53.740 --> 00:05:55.610
But interpret footage.

121
00:05:55.610 --> 00:05:58.470
Anybody who ever worked
with a film camera,

122
00:05:58.470 --> 00:06:02.240
you know that this is called
an overcrank and an undercrank.

123
00:06:03.500 --> 00:06:08.330
Technically, in the film world, okay,
film rolls through the camera only at 24

124
00:06:08.330 --> 00:06:12.930
frames a second, and it is only
projected at 24 frames a second.

125
00:06:12.930 --> 00:06:16.026
So if I wanna make it go
look like it's going faster,

126
00:06:16.026 --> 00:06:20.930
I roll it at a lower Frame Rate,
like 18 or 12 or something like that.

127
00:06:20.930 --> 00:06:24.661
If I wanna make it go slower,
I crank it up higher.

128
00:06:24.661 --> 00:06:29.553
So I could say, by the way,

129
00:06:29.553 --> 00:06:36.818
please assume the Frame Rate is 23.976.

130
00:06:36.818 --> 00:06:39.650
Please assume that, okay?

131

And then hit Return.

132
00:06:41.675 --> 00:06:44.497
Now it says 23.976.

What is that gonna look like?

00:06:47.852 --> 00:06:49.217
If I come up here.

00:06:53.721 --> 00:06:55.222
It's like why is it taking so long?

Because now it is in slow motion.

00:06:58.521 --> 00:07:00.708
So watch me,
watch me cut this thing this time.

138
00:07:02.672 --> 00:07:03.230
Come on.

139
00:07:03.230 --> 00:07:08.406
I gotta wait for
it cuz it's like much longer now, okay?

140
00:07:08.406 --> 00:07:09.580
Boom.

141
00:07:09.580 --> 00:07:12.413
And I did it this way,
and it's nice and smooth.

142
00:07:15.562 --> 00:07:17.825
It is nice and smooth.

143
00:07:17.825 --> 00:07:20.484
>> And we're doing this at
the left side of [CROSSTALK]

144
00:07:20.484 --> 00:07:21.408
>> Right, we're doing this

145
00:07:21.408 --> 00:07:22.041
at the left side.

146
00:07:22.041 --> 00:07:23.070
>> Yes.
>> And then I can cut in.

147
00:07:23.070 --> 00:07:24.670
That's one of the reasons
why I made the duplicate.

148
00:07:24.670 --> 00:07:25.490
You'll notice that.

149
00:07:25.490 --> 00:07:29.250
Now, the question is did
it affect this side?

150
00:07:30.720 --> 00:07:31.950
Yes, it did.

151
00:07:31.950 --> 00:07:34.253
Because remember there was the cut.

152
00:07:34.253 --> 00:07:40.658
So now because I changed that source
element, it has affected this side.

153
00:07:40.658 --> 00:07:44.830
>> Of where like the clip of
the duration of where you want to-

154
00:07:44.830 --> 00:07:45.810
>> Exactly.

155
00:07:45.810 --> 00:07:46.542
>> So everything shifted.

156
00:07:46.542 --> 00:07:48.180
>> And now it's shifted.

157
00:07:48.180 --> 00:07:49.280
Everything is shifted.

158
00:07:49.280 --> 00:07:53.214
So if I do the double-click,
and then zoom back,

159
00:07:53.214 --> 00:07:59.316
I could do that thing where I grab the
center and move it over and say okay move.

160
00:07:59.316 --> 00:07:59.893
Now that's not it.

161
00:07:59.893 --> 00:08:05.954
I grab this guy and I move it over And
I find where that cut was, okay?

162
00:08:05.954 --> 00:08:07.804
Come out.
There it is.

163
00:08:07.804 --> 00:08:13.360
Move it back, move it back,
move it back, move it back, cool.

164
00:08:13.360 --> 00:08:15.479
And now it adjusts here, okay?

165
00:08:15.479 --> 00:08:16.610
It adjusts here.

166
00:08:16.610 --> 00:08:18.034
Not to where I want it to.

167
00:08:18.034 --> 00:08:18.800
You know what?

168
00:08:18.800 --> 00:08:19.340
You know why?

169
00:08:19.340 --> 00:08:20.520
Cuz of where I had the Play head.

170
00:08:21.690 --> 00:08:22.600
So I'm gonna do that Play head now.

171
00:08:23.870 --> 00:08:26.944
Double-click and move it over.

172
00:08:29.365 --> 00:08:33.520
And yeah, now I get that,
and it goes nice and slow.

173
00:08:33.520 --> 00:08:36.020
Down here make sure to
click the correct panel.

174
00:08:37.090 --> 00:08:39.402
That also means I'm going to
have to stretch this out.

175
00:08:39.402 --> 00:08:46.422
I'm gonna have to do that trimming
thing and say please extend it, okay?

176

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne work with still images in Premiere Pro. They cover how to import a folder of images, modify stills duration in the preferences, and add stills to the timeline. They also demonstrate how to add markers in a clip and a sequence, then add images to the markers through the automate to sequence command. Finally, they show how to animate stills using effects parameters.
episodes.title: Working with Stills

00:28:34.552 --> 00:28:37.240
I mean, it's the ones that you
need to know what I'm doing as

545
00:28:37.240 --> 00:28:40.350
I'm going through a project because
you come back two days later, and

546
00:28:40.350 --> 00:28:42.790
I totally forgot everything
that I was supposed to do.

547
00:28:42.790 --> 00:28:44.951
But if you put markers and put little
notes on it, it's gonna be perfect.

548
00:28:44.951 --> 00:28:45.970
>> Yeah, absolutely, cool.

549
00:28:45.970 --> 00:28:48.111
So yeah, there you go.

550
00:28:48.111 --> 00:28:50.750
>> We got a pretty cool
montage going on there.

551
00:28:50.750 --> 00:28:51.363
>> It's awesome, isn't it?

552
00:28:51.363 --> 00:28:52.012
>> Yes, it is.

553
00:28:52.012 --> 00:28:52.720
>> I like it.

554
00:28:52.720 --> 00:28:53.500
>> [LAUGH] Well, awesome.

555
00:28:53.500 --> 00:28:56.300
Well, thank you so much for
sharing that with us.

556
00:28:56.300 --> 00:29:00.560
I know I'm going to go and
make all my own montages of Fuego.

557
00:29:00.560 --> 00:29:02.970
>> Everybody's getting
a Christmas present of-

558
00:29:02.970 --> 00:29:03.757
>> I am, and now,

559
00:29:03.757 --> 00:29:05.947
before I just made
the Christmas [CROSSTALK]

560
00:29:05.947 --> 00:29:07.025
>> Sorry.

561
00:29:07.025 --> 00:29:09.043
[LAUGH]
>> Now they're gonna get a video

562
00:29:09.043 --> 00:29:09.843
montage, so.

563
00:29:09.843 --> 00:29:11.686
[LAUGH] But thank you so much for that.

564
00:29:11.686 --> 00:29:14.510
But we're gonna go ahead and
wrap this on up.

565
00:29:14.510 --> 00:29:17.283
We'll go ahead and sign off this episode,
but please stay tuned.

566
00:29:17.283 --> 00:29:18.799
We're gonna have lots more to come.

567
00:29:18.799 --> 00:29:21.710
So signing off for Creative Pro TV,
I've been your host, Vonne Smith.

568
00:29:21.710 --> 00:29:22.290
>> I'm James Middle.

569
00:29:22.290 --> 00:29:23.263
>> And we'll see you soon.

570
00:29:23.263 --> 00:29:28.050
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Vonne and James continue with more effects, specifically covering speed effects. James demonstrates how to modify clip speed/duration, the rate stretch tool, and time remapping. They also cover advanced workspace manipulation.
episodes.title: Speed Effects
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:06.363
[SOUND]

2
00:00:06.363 --> 00:00:11.484
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.484 --> 00:00:15.930
Hello everyone and welcome back to another
exciting episode of Creative ProTV.

4
00:00:15.930 --> 00:00:18.790
I'm your host Vonne Smith and
we are continuing on our series for

5
00:00:18.790 --> 00:00:22.480
Adobe Premier Pro CC 2017.

6
00:00:22.480 --> 00:00:24.810
And with us in the studios is Mr.
James Biddle, hey.

7
00:00:26.210 --> 00:00:28.390
>> Hi everybody, it's good to be back.

8
00:00:28.390 --> 00:00:30.300
>> I don't know why I wanted
to just do that whole thing.

9
00:00:30.300 --> 00:00:31.650
>> I love it, you can just keep doing it.

10
00:00:31.650 --> 00:00:34.510
If glitter was thrown,
it'd be even better.

11
00:00:34.510 --> 00:00:35.070
Glitter bombs.

12
00:00:35.070 --> 00:00:36.430
>> Yes, that would be amazing.

13
00:00:36.430 --> 00:00:39.762
>> There was no glitter
bombs effect in Adobe, but.

14
00:00:39.762 --> 00:00:42.410
>> [LAUGH] But we're are gonna
be talking about speed effects.

15
00:00:42.410 --> 00:00:44.170
Does that when I talk really fast and
go, go, go, go go?

16
00:00:44.170 --> 00:00:45.412
>> Yeah, yeah, yeah.
Exactly, exactly.

17
00:00:45.412 --> 00:00:46.030
>> Cuz I do that.
[LAUGH]

18
00:00:46.030 --> 00:00:46.871
>> Yeah we're gonna be

19
00:00:46.871 --> 00:00:47.814
changing some speed.

20
00:00:47.814 --> 00:00:51.242
A lot of people ask me about,
they want to do some things they've seen.

21
00:00:51.242 --> 00:00:53.135
They wanna speed this up,
they wanna slow this down.

22
00:00:53.135 --> 00:00:54.290
How do you do it?

23
00:00:54.290 --> 00:00:55.350
Well just like everything in Adobe,

24
00:00:55.350 --> 00:00:57.900
there's about seven different ways,
maybe more.

25
00:00:57.900 --> 00:01:00.310
I don't know, but
there's a lot of different ways to do it.

26
00:01:00.310 --> 00:01:04.550
And in this case,
you use what you need to use at the time,

27
00:01:04.550 --> 00:01:07.210
not just what you prefer, okay?

28
00:01:07.210 --> 00:01:11.270
So I've got a clip here and it's just
a simple pan, or a panorama shot,

29
00:01:11.270 --> 00:01:12.820
that I did in Colombia.

30
00:01:12.820 --> 00:01:14.949
My wife is from Colombia so
this is in Medelln.

31
00:01:14.949 --> 00:01:19.940
It's a great grandeur view close
to the top of a very large rock.

32
00:01:19.940 --> 00:01:21.980
And there is audio, okay?

33
00:01:21.980 --> 00:01:26.620
Now what I've done is sort of the generic,
I am panning the camera, okay?

34
00:01:26.620 --> 00:01:29.560
And it's just that this
really slows speed.

35
00:01:31.080 --> 00:01:36.380
Which is fine, but in many cases, I'd
like to make it a little more exciting.

36
00:01:36.380 --> 00:01:38.168
How do I do that?

37
00:01:38.168 --> 00:01:40.890
All right, first of all,
we're gonna get it in a sequence.

38
00:01:40.890 --> 00:01:42.910
Last time, I made a speed change.

39
00:01:42.910 --> 00:01:47.530
What I did was I was on the left side,
the source side and I said,

40
00:01:47.530 --> 00:01:49.910
crank it down from one
frame rate to another.

41
00:01:49.910 --> 00:01:51.640
I didn't setup this shop that way.

42
00:01:51.640 --> 00:01:55.327
So, I'm going to do this in the sequence,
okay?

43
00:01:55.327 --> 00:01:58.150
Now, again,
numerous ways to make a sequence.

44
00:01:58.150 --> 00:01:59.638
I'm not gonna create a custom one.

45
00:01:59.638 --> 00:02:03.850
I'm not gonna do the whole super,
make new, and choose all that.

46
00:02:03.850 --> 00:02:10.150
Again, I can Ctrl click it, and
I can say New Sequence from Clip.

47
00:02:10.150 --> 00:02:17.240
Or I can simply drag it over the New Item
icon which is right over here.

48
00:02:17.240 --> 00:02:19.860
Come here, come here sweetie,
just come here.

49
00:02:19.860 --> 00:02:22.210
It's not gonna, it hates me today, okay.

50
00:02:22.210 --> 00:02:25.110
I could drag it over this right here,
and it will do the same thing.

51
00:02:25.110 --> 00:02:28.180
Or, notice drag media
here to create sequence.

52
00:02:28.180 --> 00:02:31.170
Click, drag, sequence.

53
00:02:31.170 --> 00:02:34.030
So it's like there
are numerous ways to do this.

54
00:02:34.030 --> 00:02:38.790
Now, you will notice there
are markers here, okay?

55
00:02:38.790 --> 00:02:42.460
Because these are source markers,
I put them on the source,

56
00:02:42.460 --> 00:02:46.350
they will translate down into
the timeline if I allow that.

57
00:02:47.490 --> 00:02:53.325
In some cases I may say that I
don't want to see clip markers.

58
00:02:53.325 --> 00:02:55.100
>> And this might be a silly question.

59
00:02:55.100 --> 00:02:57.210
How did you get the markers
in your source file?

60
00:02:57.210 --> 00:03:00.450
Like on the actual device that
you used to record it with?

61
00:03:00.450 --> 00:03:05.610
>> Well, actually that's a great question,
because there is a side program that

62
00:03:05.610 --> 00:03:09.020
you can use on an iPad,
which will do that.

63
00:03:09.020 --> 00:03:13.950
Or in most cases, again,
I can just come through here and

64
00:03:13.950 --> 00:03:16.567
then hit the m key, and
it pops a marker, okay?

65
00:03:17.860 --> 00:03:20.490
And notice it updated it down here.

66
00:03:20.490 --> 00:03:22.100
So it updated me to four.

67
00:03:22.100 --> 00:03:24.160
>> But you didn't bring this into
Premiere and put the markers on.

68
00:03:24.160 --> 00:03:25.393
You're saying you did
that on a separate film.

69
00:03:25.393 --> 00:03:28.694
>> No, no I just, no, no, but
there is a way to do that.

70
00:03:28.694 --> 00:03:30.375
>> Okay.
>> Which we're gonna cover a little

71
00:03:30.375 --> 00:03:33.890
bit later, that some people adore,
and some people absolutely hate.

72
00:03:33.890 --> 00:03:38.160
But, I can do it right here, and
I just did these beforehand.

73
00:03:38.160 --> 00:03:40.368
I prepped them before you got here.

74
00:03:40.368 --> 00:03:40.920
>> Okay.

75
00:03:40.920 --> 00:03:41.747
I'm just making sure I
didn't miss anything.

76
00:03:41.747 --> 00:03:43.297
>> I threw you a curve ball.

77
00:03:43.297 --> 00:03:45.029
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, I threw you a curve ball.

78
00:03:45.029 --> 00:03:46.485
And I stayed up and did it, I'm sorry.

79
00:03:46.485 --> 00:03:51.113
>> [LAUGH] I was making sure,
I was like, does your camera do that?

80
00:03:51.113 --> 00:03:51.721
[LAUGH]
>> No, well,

81
00:03:51.721 --> 00:03:55.025
like I said there are some devices
where you can get something like this.

82
00:03:55.025 --> 00:03:59.880
Now, I'm gonna change to my workspace and
create a call editing LT,

83
00:03:59.880 --> 00:04:02.823
where I get a really long thing like that.

84
00:04:02.823 --> 00:04:05.580
All right, so how do I manipulate time?

85
00:04:06.790 --> 00:04:08.680
There's several different ways.

86
00:04:08.680 --> 00:04:14.630
Since this is linked I can Ctrl click it,
scroll down.

87
00:04:14.630 --> 00:04:16.800
And notice there's a thing
called Speed and Duration.

88
00:04:18.960 --> 00:04:23.456
And what I can do is I can give
it an overall speed change.

89
00:04:23.456 --> 00:04:26.921
Like I could say, let's say I'd
like this to be a little faster,

90
00:04:26.921 --> 00:04:28.720
I'd like it to go up to 150%.

91
00:04:28.720 --> 00:04:33.058
Now that doesn't mean, it just means 150%.

92
00:04:33.058 --> 00:04:36.113
Not 100%, 150%, okay?

93
00:04:36.113 --> 00:04:39.510
And it's telling me the new duration and
they are locked.

94
00:04:39.510 --> 00:04:44.900
Now, I can say maintain the audio
pitch if I care about the audio.

95
00:04:44.900 --> 00:04:46.940
And it will do its best to maintain pitch,

96
00:04:46.940 --> 00:04:51.483
so it doesn't sound all squeaky chipmunk,
okay?

97
00:04:51.483 --> 00:04:56.356
Or, squishy deep voice,
if I make it slower, okay?

98
00:04:56.356 --> 00:04:58.320
I have different types of interpolation.

99
00:04:58.320 --> 00:05:02.530
I can do Frame Sampling,
Frame Blending, Optical Flow.

100
00:05:02.530 --> 00:05:07.160
Honestly, the best way to learn about
this is just go through the online help

101
00:05:07.160 --> 00:05:08.550
as to which one.

102
00:05:08.550 --> 00:05:10.730
Right now,
I'm just gonna do Frame Sampling.

103
00:05:10.730 --> 00:05:15.481
Taking samples of frames
to create new frames, okay?

104
00:05:15.481 --> 00:05:20.393
The optical flow, this is sort of like
the super amazing version of this,

105
00:05:20.393 --> 00:05:23.500
but you better have some
great media in there.

106
00:05:23.500 --> 00:05:26.117
I have got phone media in there.

107
00:05:26.117 --> 00:05:28.452
So the frame sampling,
to me, is just fine.

108
00:05:28.452 --> 00:05:29.780
I can also reverse this.

109
00:05:29.780 --> 00:05:33.030
This is the easiest way to reverse it,
make it go backwards.

110
00:05:33.030 --> 00:05:37.400
Ripple Edit, Shifting Trailing Clips,
I'm gonna demonstrate this in a second.

111
00:05:37.400 --> 00:05:39.860
So I click OK, and
I've made an overall speed change.

112
00:05:39.860 --> 00:05:42.560
This is what throws people,
it seems to be shorter.

113
00:05:42.560 --> 00:05:46.650
Well of course, it's faster so
it's not gonna take as much time.

114
00:05:46.650 --> 00:05:48.130
So, here we go.

115
00:05:48.130 --> 00:05:51.600
It's rendering out, and there it is.

116
00:05:51.600 --> 00:05:54.830
It's going a little bit
faster than before, okay?

117
00:05:54.830 --> 00:05:57.260
So that's just an overall speed change.

118
00:05:58.470 --> 00:06:01.459
If I had another clip on
the other end of this,

119
00:06:01.459 --> 00:06:05.330
I'm just gonna drag something
over very quickly, okay?

120
00:06:05.330 --> 00:06:05.859
And watch.

121
00:06:05.859 --> 00:06:07.250
I'm not even gonna put
it in the source window.

122
00:06:07.250 --> 00:06:10.416
I'm just gonna drag and
pop it right there, and

123
00:06:10.416 --> 00:06:12.802
I made the effective speed change.

124
00:06:12.802 --> 00:06:14.882
Do the same thing, Ctrl.

125
00:06:14.882 --> 00:06:18.090
[INAUDIBLE] Speed duration.

126
00:06:18.090 --> 00:06:20.639
In this case I"m going to make it 50%,

127
00:06:20.639 --> 00:06:24.390
I'm gonna slow it down,
maintain the audio pitch.

128
00:06:24.390 --> 00:06:26.040
Now what does this mean?

129
00:06:26.040 --> 00:06:29.400
Ripple Edit, Shifting Trailing Clips.

130
00:06:29.400 --> 00:06:31.670
Remember when we were
doing ripple edits and

131
00:06:31.670 --> 00:06:35.000
I said if you do
a one-sided it affects it?

132
00:06:35.000 --> 00:06:35.520
Okay?

133
00:06:35.520 --> 00:06:38.090
Things are gonna move forward or backward.

134
00:06:38.090 --> 00:06:45.480
If this is off, okay,
it keeps it there, okay?

135
00:06:45.480 --> 00:06:46.300
It's slower.

136
00:06:46.300 --> 00:06:48.860
Let me speed it up to show you.

137
00:06:48.860 --> 00:06:53.381
Slowing down isn't gonna give
you sort of the right look.

138
00:06:53.381 --> 00:06:59.708
Let me speed it up to 200%,
maintain the audio pitch.

139
00:07:02.420 --> 00:07:04.020
Boom.

140
00:07:04.020 --> 00:07:07.770
Nothing moves, nothing on the opposite
end moves, it doesn't ripple.

141
00:07:09.960 --> 00:07:12.300
If I do it one more time,
I know this seems pretty tedious, but

142
00:07:12.300 --> 00:07:15.940
I want everybody to see every
single example of what can happen.

143
00:07:15.940 --> 00:07:17.940
Because there's a lot of choices.

144
00:07:17.940 --> 00:07:22.380
Speed duration and if I say, let's go 300.

145
00:07:22.380 --> 00:07:26.660
Let's go kinda crazy, and
then say ripple the edit.

146
00:07:29.000 --> 00:07:29.970
It moves.

147
00:07:29.970 --> 00:07:34.530
So that means the entire, there are more
things back there all of it would move.

148
00:07:34.530 --> 00:07:36.360
All of it would move, okay?

149
00:07:36.360 --> 00:07:38.300
So that's what the ripple portion means.

150
00:07:38.300 --> 00:07:40.930
It does the entire segment.

151
00:07:40.930 --> 00:07:42.890
It does the entire segment.

152
00:07:42.890 --> 00:07:45.730
Sometimes that's what you want.

153
00:07:45.730 --> 00:07:50.345
Sometimes you're not so sure.

154
00:07:50.345 --> 00:07:52.920
I'm gonna get rid of this one so
I can demonstrate a little better.

155
00:07:52.920 --> 00:07:56.818
Sometimes you're not sure how much you
want to speed it up or slow it down.

156
00:07:56.818 --> 00:07:59.697
So there's a tool for that, okay?

157
00:07:59.697 --> 00:08:04.381
And I think I made my tools go away,
which was a silly thing to do.

158
00:08:04.381 --> 00:08:07.723
But if I go to Window and say Tools,

159
00:08:07.723 --> 00:08:13.380
op not Timelines, Tools,
it pops back up for me.

160
00:08:13.380 --> 00:08:17.040
You know I got rid of it,
I lost it, so there it is.

161
00:08:17.040 --> 00:08:21.460
I'm gonna come over here and if you
remember there was the ripple edit tool.

162
00:08:22.630 --> 00:08:28.140
If I click here, Scroll down,
I get a Rate Stretch Tool.

163
00:08:29.820 --> 00:08:32.710
So now it's the Rate Stretch Tool,
and many people are familiar

164
00:08:32.710 --> 00:08:35.650
with this from other systems they
may have worked around with.

165
00:08:35.650 --> 00:08:42.090
If I grab the ends, and stretch it out,
it's now telling me the new duration, ok?

166
00:08:42.090 --> 00:08:43.460
Now it's really slow.

167
00:08:46.820 --> 00:08:48.190
There was no pitch option.

168
00:08:49.540 --> 00:08:52.140
There is no maintaining pitch
option anything like that.

169
00:08:52.140 --> 00:08:56.270
It's just a really fast stretching
the rate, making it really, and

170
00:08:56.270 --> 00:08:58.640
you get let me just stretch out the view.

171
00:09:00.080 --> 00:09:02.820
It gives you the percentage of
how fast it's going now, so

172
00:09:02.820 --> 00:09:04.335
it's going at 358 percent.

173
00:09:04.335 --> 00:09:08.690
[SOUND] And everybody's all
squeaky chipmunk people so okay.

174
00:09:08.690 --> 00:09:10.146
Now.

175
00:09:10.146 --> 00:09:13.190
>> So you don't have as
many options with the tool.

176
00:09:13.190 --> 00:09:14.630
>> You don't have as many
options with the tool.

177
00:09:14.630 --> 00:09:19.335
>> But sometimes you just need to affect
a really quick rate change and it's fine.

178
00:09:20.665 --> 00:09:26.685
Now, now let's get to the final portion.

179
00:09:26.685 --> 00:09:31.298
This is where somebody says so, I've been
watching this show called Top Gear and you

180
00:09:31.298 --> 00:09:36.475
go, and
that's where you want it to speed up and

181
00:09:36.475 --> 00:09:40.220
then, slow down and then, speed back
up and then, go to normal speed.

182
00:09:40.220 --> 00:09:44.110
Okay, so that is called time remapping.

183
00:09:45.410 --> 00:09:48.200
And we're gonna set up
the timeline to do this.

184
00:09:49.650 --> 00:09:52.730
I'm actually gonna go back into
the editing workspace cuz I'm gonna need

185
00:09:52.730 --> 00:09:53.610
a few things in there.

186
00:09:53.610 --> 00:09:57.650
Let me squish this up, squish that up.

187
00:09:57.650 --> 00:09:58.370
Okay, good.

188
00:09:58.370 --> 00:10:04.350
Now I'm gonna make a big, big

189
00:10:04.350 --> 00:10:09.510
Video here cuz believe it or not, and
this often frustrates people when

190
00:10:09.510 --> 00:10:15.110
they first get into this time remapping
and they go, I'm gonna remap it all this.

191
00:10:15.110 --> 00:10:21.965
Time remapping doesn't do Dp audio,
it won't go anywhere near audio, okay?

192
00:10:21.965 --> 00:10:26.505
If you use the tool,
if you use speed duration, yes, okay?

193
00:10:26.505 --> 00:10:30.705
Or if you do the over crank,
under crank and modifying interpolation,

194
00:10:30.705 --> 00:10:31.815
yeah it will do that.

195
00:10:31.815 --> 00:10:36.310
This, absolutely not, this is video Only.

196
00:10:36.310 --> 00:10:38.870
If you need to manipulate the audio
you're going to have to go out and

197
00:10:38.870 --> 00:10:39.830
figure out how to do that.

198
00:10:39.830 --> 00:10:40.430
Okay.

199
00:10:40.430 --> 00:10:42.530
There's a lot of ways but
it's a lot of work.

200
00:10:42.530 --> 00:10:45.630
So I'm just going to
leave the audio on there.

201
00:10:45.630 --> 00:10:49.120
Another thing that I'm going to need
is I'm going to need those effect

202
00:10:49.120 --> 00:10:50.640
badges again.

203
00:10:50.640 --> 00:10:53.250
So you got the little FX on there, okay.

204
00:10:53.250 --> 00:10:54.130
I need that.

205
00:10:54.130 --> 00:10:58.030
If I don't have that,

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne dive into the world of color correction in Premiere Pro. They review the lumetri scope panel and how to read the graphs. They also demonstrate how to use the basic correction, creative, and curves panels within the lumetri color panel group.
episodes.title: Color Correction

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne continue to explore how to color correct in Premiere Pro. They demonstrate how to use the color wheels, HSL secondary, and vignette panels within the lumetri color panel group. They also cover adjustment layers and review some obsolete effects.
episodes.title: Even More Color Correction

we're doing this new Lumtri Color setup.

The workspace called Color.

In Premiere Pro, working our way down.

And if we go back,
we'd just gone past curves, okay?

And we had a lovely conversation about

18
00:00:51.180 --> 00:00:56.150
So curves is, if you use Photoshop

19
00:00:56.150 --> 00:01:01.860
Okay, because when you do like a photo,
or if you used to do film.

20
00:01:01.860 --> 00:01:06.380
When you would process it, the
relationship between the colors affected,

21
00:01:06.380 --> 00:01:08.540
what was bright, what was dark,
what was mid tone.

22
00:01:08.540 --> 00:01:12.490
Okay, well, in television,
that wasn't really the case.

23
00:01:12.490 --> 00:01:14.940
They used to send the signal to you.

24
00:01:14.940 --> 00:01:19.400
As the luma was bright, dark,
and mid-tone in one signal.

25
00:01:19.400 --> 00:01:22.910
And then they would send the chroma
information, red, green,

26
00:01:22.910 --> 00:01:26.550
blue, in a separate signal so people could
still have black and white televisions and

27
00:01:26.550 --> 00:01:27.610
still get signal.

28
00:01:27.610 --> 00:01:32.450
So when you go to color wheels,
okay, you have a slider, and

29

mid-tones, and highlights.

30
00:01:37.510 --> 00:01:40.080

31
00:01:40.080 --> 00:01:43.610
What's bright and dark in the mid tones,

32
00:01:43.610 --> 00:01:47.660
Then you have a color wheel,
to adjust color,

33
00:01:47.660 --> 00:01:50.220
the hue of the color
that's being affected.

34
00:01:51.390 --> 00:01:53.950
That's why they call it hue, saturation.

35
00:01:53.950 --> 00:01:55.910
They call it HSL color wheels.

36
00:01:55.910 --> 00:01:58.070
In this case they just

37
00:01:58.070 --> 00:02:02.290
So one of the reasons I might
want to do that is this,

I mean it's a nice shot but because of the

00:02:06.730 --> 00:02:09.640
I've also noticed that my

Now, when you start reading about color

everybody has theories about these

It's like shadows or

That's what a lot of
us just say to people,

47
00:02:29.470 --> 00:02:31.510
it's like that's just what you do okay?

48

So I usually start with shadows and

what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna

So that there's not that crush at zero.

Now I'll take the highlights and

That would equate to

Okay, throw a little blue in

episodes.description: James and Vonne cover the essentials of sound editing. They review the audio settings in the preferences, the merge clips command, and the audio track mixer. They also cover how to add effects and create a live mix in the audio track mixer.

episodes.description: Make it pop! This is every designer or editors favorite request. In this episode, James demonstrates some fun tips and tricks while combining and expanding upon all the skills covered in the previous episodes so far in the series. He explores the shadow highlight effect, creating a vignette using the legacy vignette using the legacy title tool and opacity, and nesting clips.
episodes.title: Make it Pop

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne discuss how to setup a shoot with multiple cameras and creating a multicamera source sequence in Premiere Pro. James also demonstrates how to edit in real time with the multicamera view in the program monitor.
episodes.title: Mulitcamera Editing

episodes.description: 360 degree video is the new wild wild west of video editing.  In this episode, James introduces how Premiere Pro works with 360 video and audio. He discusses creating a new VR sequence and its settings, switching VR display mode in the program panel, adding the binaural effect on the master track in the track mixer, adding the panner ambisonic effect on the track in the timeline, and exporting options.
episodes.title: 360 Degree Video

20

00:01:03.732 --> 00:01:05.996

[LAUGH]

00:01:11.632 --> 00:01:16.780
So what you're really doing is,

25
00:01:16.780 --> 00:01:20.005
And there's several different types

26
00:01:20.005 --> 00:01:21.597

So a couple of things.

You're like, no, you're so

It's one of those check boxes that

If this wasn't, then I would have to go

And there it is.

Yeah, boom, new item,

episodes.description: There are other programs within the Creative Cloud that can help step up your productivity. In this episode, James demonstrates how Prelude CC can assist in inputting media as well as Media Encoder to help with outputting finished sequences. He also reviews the remove unused command, the project manager, and how to create new ingest presets.
episodes.title: Step Up Your Input and Output
